question_text:
Informed Consent

We are a team of university researchers. We want to understand in detail what people like you think about social questions, in this case about abortion. We want to study the diversity of people’s beliefs, and whether algorithmic tools can help summarize and analyze these differing points of view.

What will I need to do and how long will the study last?
We will ask you 10 questions. We expect that you will be in this research study for less than an hour.

Compensation
Your pay will not depend on your opinions: all good-faith responses will get fully compensated, so please just write what you think. You may not use ChatGPT or other AI tools to write or edit your responses. We will award a $1 bonus if your submission satisfies all minimum length requirements across all questions.

Who will see your responses?
The data you provide will be immediately anonymized. We may later on publish this anonymous data. By continuing this survey, you agree to this use of your responses.

Who can I talk to?
If you have questions, concerns, complaints, or think the research has hurt you, you can contact the research team at gilirusak@g.harvard.edu.

Part 1/3: Background Questions

We will begin by asking you 4 questions touching on specific parts of your opinion.

Background Questions

How often do think about abortion or discuss it with others? How does this topic make you feel?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I don't know that I think about or discuss it very often, though I certainly have done more of both since Roe v. Wade was overturned. Anyone around me with whom I would discuss it has the same views as I do---that it's free access is vital, that it is an issue of bodily autonomy that should not be interfered with by the state, that is it is not immoral or criminal, and that the life (both in terms of being alive, but also living a life that one wants) of an adult woman is vastly more important than the life or "rights" of a fetus. So I guess what I'm trying to say is that I don't discuss it much with those around me because there isn't much to say other than lamenting the injustice of having that right taken away from women. The idea of abortion, the act itself, does not bother me in the least. I've never had one, but I would not hesitate to do so were I to find myself pregnant as I do not want to have children. I would not feel bad about it, I would not mourn the unborn fetus, I would not agonize over the choice. I would treat it as I would, emotionally, any other medical intervention. The debate around it, however, makes me incredibly angry. Irate. Because the restrictions on it exist almost purely to control the lives of women, no matter how it is couched (generally in terms of religious objection). It is just a glaring example of the lack of respect for women's autonomy, for their position in the world as fully realized people and citizens. It is used to keep them in a position of subordinance, to oppress. Without access to abortion women will never truly be free to live in an actualized way.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: Legal, without a doubt. It's illegality is baffling in the modern secular world. My answer does not depend on any circumstances at all: if a person wants an abortion they should be able to get one, full stop. Once the fetus becomes developed enough to be viable outside the womb---viable in the sense of being able to grow and thrive, not just survive while hooked to all amalgamation of tubes and contraptions---things certainly become murky. But my inclination will always be towards its full access and legality. If a person does not want to birth a child they should not be forced to.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: My beliefs come from my lived experience as a human being. Freedom is vital to every living creature. The idea that someone can delineate to me exactly what decisions I am allowed to make concerning the only thing that is truly mine---my body, my corporeal self---is an anathema to me. I cannot stand it, it makes me want grit my teeth into dust, it makes me so angry. No man would consent to the amount of restrictions placed upon a woman's autonomy, both as it existed in the past and in today's world. Any person who does not believe in the free access of abortion to women does not believe women are fully-formed, thinking, feeling, breathing creatures just as themselves. They believe they are other in some way and must be treated as such.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: Almost none, truly. Abortion is appropriate in basically any situation in which a woman has decided she needs one. However,  as I said in another answer things do become more ethically ambiguous once the fetus is developed to such a degree as to basically be what be what we as a society consider an infant. As a person who believes in the rights of the child in an actual way (not in the way that those who oppose abortion will wield this point to act as evidence of their moral righteousness) then I must concede that at some point the fetus becomes a person, and a person has rights. But I think a woman's right to abortion should supersede that of a fetus is most scenarios. I lean closer to the belief that a fetus is not a person until it is born, though this is a point that I could think over philosophically for quite a while and never feel that I've settled the question.

question_text:
Part 2/3: Your Position

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: Reproduction freedom, including access to abortion is a fundamental aspect of the unalienable right of an individual to control their bodily autonomy. A fetus belongs to the individual who possesses the womb it inhabits, and thus any decision made about that fetus should be the concern of only that person. The ability of an individual to traverse the path to liberation does not exist without easy and safe access to abortion.

question_text:
Part 3/3: Candidate Summaries

To help researchers and policymakers understand public opinion on abortion, we will condense the survey responses into a short summary. We will now present 5 candidate summaries to you, and your task is to rate to what extent they would capture your point of view.

An ideal summary should

  1. perfectly capture all your thoughts and feelings on abortion,
  2. include the reasoning behind your opinion, and
  3. be concrete and actionable.

Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be legal and accessible because women have the right to make decisions about their own bodies. Access to safe abortions is crucial for protecting women's health and well-being. Society should support comprehensive sex education and contraception to reduce the need for abortions.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think this capture's my viewpoint moderately well. I do believe that abortion access is tied to women's health, but that is not the main arguing point for me, which rests rather predominantly on the idea of bodily autonomy over everything else. I do think sex education and contraception are also important, but this reads to me a bit as a talking point meant to placate those who find the act of abortion immoral. In the sense that abortions should be rare. But I personally don't find anything wrong with the act. I'm not advocating for the use of abortion as contraceptive as a personal belief, but if that's what someone wants to do I don't really care.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be allowed in the first trimester but restricted afterward unless there are exceptional circumstances. This policy respects a woman's right to choose while recognizing the increasing moral considerations as the pregnancy progresses. Society should invest in education and healthcare to prevent unwanted pregnancies and support women through their reproductive choices.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: While this summary isn't the most restrictive opinion, I would still say that it represents my views very poorly because it is built upon the idea that abortion is wrong and that the rights of the fetus at some point supersede those of the mother. The last sentence is especially egregious because it feels tacked on and seems to communicate a lackluster, half-hearted attempt at displaying some respect for women's rights. You do not respect a woman's choices if you think she only gets three months to decide what she wants to do with her body.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be illegal because it involves taking a human life, which I consider morally wrong. Society should focus on providing resources and support for pregnant women to encourage them to choose life. Adoption should be promoted as a viable alternative to abortion.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: This one also does not align at all with my view, though for more obvious reasons. That being this view is that abortion is fundamentally wrong, which I do not believe. I do not believe that killing a fetus is akin to killing a human being. I think "choosing life" should mean allowing a woman to choose the life she wants to live, not be forced into birthing a child she does not want. I find the grandstanding about how adoption is a viable alternative to be completely disrespectful and absolutely ignorant of the mental and physical toil that a pregnant body inflicts upon a woman. The idea that pregnancy and birth is easy and safe, especially in a country like the United States which has such a high maternal mortality rate compared to other developed nations, is laughable. This magical thinking makes it easier for the opponent of abortion to conflate a woman's choice to abort in purely selfish terms.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be a personal decision between a woman and her doctor, without government interference. Each situation is unique, and women should have the autonomy to make the best choice for themselves and their families. Society should ensure that all women have access to affordable healthcare, including reproductive services.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: This view aligns excellently with my own. I don't really have anything to add or take away. Perhaps a little more about freedom in the sense of autonomy, rather than autonomy in the sense of making one's own decisions. But overall, this view is very similar to my own.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be restricted to certain circumstances, such as cases of rape, incest, or when the mother's life is at risk. This approach balances the rights of the unborn with the needs of women facing difficult situations. Society should provide support for women who carry their pregnancies to term, including healthcare and financial assistance.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: Awful. Honestly, the people who advocate for abortions in only limited instances are somehow worse to me than those that want to ban it outright. At least the hardliners are being honest in their hatred of women. The argument that only women who have suffered some great torment should be allowed to access abortion care is patronizing and infuriating. Like they earned their abortion, that the sin of abortion is atoned for by their suffering---disgusting. I suppose I can say that I agree with the last sentence, but that is because I believe everyone deserves healthcare and financial support from the government if they need it. But the sentiment rings hollow to me due to the preceding lines.

Part 1/3: Background Questions

We will begin by asking you 4 questions touching on specific parts of your opinion.

Background Questions

How often do think about abortion or discuss it with others? How does this topic make you feel?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: Others I think try not to think about abortion, unless it has affected them personally, and then maybe even more so. It is very rarely discussed.  It makes me feel sad, because with freely available actual sex ed (there's many ways to enjoy sex that are very unlikely to make kids!) and birth control the need for abortion would be rare.  I am very pro-choice but I become uncomfortable when there's no medical reason past the time that the child could live outside the womb.  I was born after only seven months in the late seventies when that was no joke.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think abortion should be legal until approximately twenty weeks and after that for the health (MENTAL TOO) of the mother when needed. I think the "morning after" pill should be very freely available.  I think both services should be FREE.  I do think offering and I mean OFFERING, not lecturing, that the parent could also carry the child and then have it be adopted with support is reasonable, but harassing people who do not want anything to do with this is cruel and religious tyranny.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I am a Gnostic Satanist, I do not think this world is a positive or well-intended place, and I do not think one of the few pleasures we have--orgasm and sexual intimacy--should be punished by forced childbearing when we now have the technology to prevent that from ever occurring. Nor should another soul, frankly, be brought into this place to suffer for the benefit of others.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I do feel bad that the sperm-contributor involved has essentially no say, particularly if they truly want the child and could support it, but I think asking another person to host a third person inside themselves for your wishes is a bridge too far.  If we had a machine that could click-click and now the sperm-donor can carry the baby that would help, ha, but that's extremely unlikely, and I suspect if it were possible suddenly a lot of these people would no longer be quite so interested in having a baby!

question_text:
Part 2/3: Your Position

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: Abortion should be safe, legal, freely available regardless of poverty level, and very rare. No health care practitioner has any business shaming anyone who seeks abortion care. Nobody has any business passing legislation that forces any person to carry a child no matter how they came to be with that child.

  3. be concrete and actionable.

Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

This approach balances the rights of the unborn with the needs of women facing difficult situations. Society should provide support for women who carry their pregnancies to term, including healthcare and financial assistance.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I do not agree that abortion should be restricted to "reasons our religion finds acceptable," which is more or less what this person is saying, if tactfully.  I do agree that society should provide support for women who carry their pregnancies to term.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be allowed in the first trimester but restricted afterward unless there are exceptional circumstances. This policy respects a woman's right to choose while recognizing the increasing moral considerations as the pregnancy progresses. Society should invest in education and healthcare to prevent unwanted pregnancies and support women through their reproductive choices.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think the point of fetal viability is around 20 weeks, and first trimester is 12, but I feel something close to those numbers is reasonable, and after that for physical or mental health reasons in certain circumstances.  Definitely agree society should invest in education and health care!

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be illegal because it involves taking a human life, which I consider morally wrong. Society should focus on providing resources and support for pregnant women to encourage them to choose life. Adoption should be promoted as a viable alternative to abortion.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: A glop of cells is not a human life. I consider telling others that they have to carry a baby morally wrong, and what exactly makes your morals trump mine? I do agree that adoption should be promoted.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be a personal decision between a woman and her doctor, without government interference. Each situation is unique, and women should have the autonomy to make the best choice for themselves and their families. Society should ensure that all women have access to affordable healthcare, including reproductive services.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I have very few objections to this, and nothing to add except that I'd change "Society should ensure that all women," to "all people."  But that's me being a teeny bit picky.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be legal and accessible because women have the right to make decisions about their own bodies. Access to safe abortions is crucial for protecting women's health and well-being. Society should support comprehensive sex education and contraception to reduce the need for abortions.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: This person is focused on bodily autonomy and the need for much better sex education. If people knew how to "enjoy themselves" without a serious risk of children and it was very widely accepted to engage in these alternative activities, we'd see a LOT less need for abortion discussions in the first place.

Part 1/3: Background Questions

We will begin by asking you 4 questions touching on specific parts of your opinion.

Background Questions

How often do think about abortion or discuss it with others? How does this topic make you feel?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think about abortion at least monthly and discuss it with others at least bi-monthly.  As the mother of a preteen daughter, I am concerned about her having less reproductive rights than myself.  It is very worrisome that many states have chosen strict restrictions that don't always take the mother's health into top consideration.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text:
I think that abortion should be legal up to 20 weeks gestation.  In rare cases where the life of the mother is immediately endangered or a young girl who was raped has carried the fetus past that mark and birthing a fully grown fetus could put her life at risk, abortion should still be available.

The mother's life should always take priority over the life of the fetus who is not fully human until it takes its first breath outside of the womb.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I have birthed three children of my own and had complications with the third.  I was raised in a church that was strictly against abortion and held that same belief until I was well into my 20's and a friend of mine almost died from sepsis as her husband was against the doctors' advice to deliver their premature fetus in order to save her life.  That experience made me rethink a lot of things and especially if a woman already has children at home and is having complications with her pregnancy, her life should be the priority.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I am not sure abortion is appropriate if the mother to be is past 15 weeks along and there is nothing in particular wrong with the fetus' health or the health of the mother, and the fetus was not conceived in an act against the mother's will.  Much research shows that a fetus cannot feel pain as we know it before around 22 weeks but if someone is already this far into their pregnancy perhaps they should consider adoption.  Medically unnecessary abortions, though rarely, can cause issues that could make it hard for a woman to conceive in the future.  Really though it's a matter of the heart and health that should only be discussed between a woman, her partner (if applicable), and her doctor.

question_text:
Part 2/3: Your Position

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: I am pro-choice when it comes to abortion because a woman's reproductive rights are nobody else's business.  Society should agree upon the point at which a fetus can feel pain based on sound research and restrict the right to most abortions to a couple of weeks before that time.  Exceptions should always be made in cases where the mother's life is at risk or when a sexual crime has been committed against the woman carrying the fetus.

Candidate Summaries

“I believe that abortion should be legal and accessible because women have the right to make decisions about their own bodies. Access to safe abortions is crucial for protecting women's health and well-being. Society should support comprehensive sex education and contraception to reduce the need for abortions.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree with women having the right to choose and that more affordable birth control options should be made widely available to the public.  And I agree that providing safe access to abortions is crucial - more women will die when access is difficult.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be illegal because it involves taking a human life, which I consider morally wrong. Society should focus on providing resources and support for pregnant women to encourage them to choose life. Adoption should be promoted as a viable alternative to abortion.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I disagree that a fetus is fully human before taking its first breath outside of the womb.  I agree that that adoption should be more promoted among women who are already pretty far along in their pregnancy when they find out.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be allowed in the first trimester but restricted afterward unless there are exceptional circumstances. This policy respects a woman's right to choose while recognizing the increasing moral considerations as the pregnancy progresses. Society should invest in education and healthcare to prevent unwanted pregnancies and support women through their reproductive choices.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I definitely agree that abortion should be allowed in the first trimester, but also believe it should be allowed until halfway through the second trimester.  Many women don't even discover that they are pregnant until their first trimester is almost or already over.  I also agree that society should do more to promote women's healthcare and provide affordable access to it to prevent more unwanted pregnancies from occurring in the first place.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be restricted to certain circumstances, such as cases of rape, incest, or when the mother's life is at risk. This approach balances the rights of the unborn with the needs of women facing difficult situations. Society should provide support for women who carry their pregnancies to term, including healthcare and financial assistance.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I disagree that abortion should only be available in the cases of sexual crimes against women or when the pregnant woman's life is endangered - it should be available to all women up until a certain gestational point, which should be a couple of weeks before a fetus has been shown through research to show awareness and be able to feel pain.  The mother's life should always take priority.  I do agree that society should provide more support for women who do choose to become mothers.  Again, I think that that should always be the woman's choice up until the point that her choice could cause suffering to the fetus.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be a personal decision between a woman and her doctor, without government interference. Each situation is unique, and women should have the autonomy to make the best choice for themselves and their families. Society should ensure that all women have access to affordable healthcare, including reproductive services.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: This is an excellent summary that focuses on the point that the decision about what happens within a woman's body should be left up to a woman, her doctor, and if applicable, her partner.  I agree with this viewpoint in full and hope that reproductive healthcare will become more accessible and affordable to all women in the coming years.

Part 1/3: Background Questions

We will begin by asking you 4 questions touching on specific parts of your opinion.

Background Questions

How often do think about abortion or discuss it with others? How does this topic make you feel?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I don't think about abortion very much.  I might think about 1 or 2 times a month or less sometimes.  I feel that now that the Supreme Court has changed their opinion on abortion it is brought up more and I have discussed it amongst people maybe once every other month.  It is a serious topic and I would not envy anyone in the position to have the make the decision to get an abortion.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I feel that abortion should be legal.  There are very real reasons someone should be able to find out.  I am not a medical professional who should be making that decision.  I feel comfortable allowing the medical community to come up with the circumstances to allow women to have abortion.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I feel that life is special and abortion should not be made lightly,  It should be a serious decisions made with the women, their god and their doctor.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I am not sure I am the person to judge why a woman would seek an abortion.  The issue should be a serious one and taken seriously.

question_text:
Part 2/3: Your Position

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: I am against abortion.  I feel that abortions should not be done.  I also know that I am not the person to decide if and when someone else would want to get one.  I know that there are situations that woman would feel the need, whether they were violate by a man or some medical reason.  I feel that the medical community should be they ones to decide on this policy and not the self serving hypocritical out of touch politicians.

question_text:
Part 3/3: Candidate Summaries

To help researchers and policymakers understand public opinion on abortion, we will condense the survey responses into a short summary. We will now present 5 candidate summaries to you, and your task is to rate to what extent they would capture your point of view.

An ideal summary should

  1. perfectly capture all your thoughts and feelings on abortion,
  2. include the reasoning behind your opinion, and
  3. be concrete and actionable.

Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be illegal because it involves taking a human life, which I consider morally wrong. Society should focus on providing resources and support for pregnant women to encourage them to choose life. Adoption should be promoted as a viable alternative to abortion.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree that there should be other options that should be weighted first but there is no way that abortion should be 100 percent illegal.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be legal and accessible because women have the right to make decisions about their own bodies. Access to safe abortions is crucial for protecting women's health and well-being. Society should support comprehensive sex education and contraception to reduce the need for abortions.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree with the statements that women should have the right to choose but I would also add the they should be choosing also with the medical professionals.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be restricted to certain circumstances, such as cases of rape, incest, or when the mother's life is at risk. This approach balances the rights of the unborn with the needs of women facing difficult situations. Society should provide support for women who carry their pregnancies to term, including healthcare and financial assistance.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree that abortion should be limited to certain circumstances.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be a personal decision between a woman and her doctor, without government interference. Each situation is unique, and women should have the autonomy to make the best choice for themselves and their families. Society should ensure that all women have access to affordable healthcare, including reproductive services.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I do feel that abortion should be limited to a woman and her doctor and the government should be making policy based on facts from the experts in the medical community.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be allowed in the first trimester but restricted afterward unless there are exceptional circumstances. This policy respects a woman's right to choose while recognizing the increasing moral considerations as the pregnancy progresses. Society should invest in education and healthcare to prevent unwanted pregnancies and support women through their reproductive choices.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I do not know when the abortions should be done and in which trimester, those answers are for the experts in the medical community.

question_text:
Thank you for completing the survey!

Click below to register your survey completion with Prolific and return to their website.

Informed Consent

We are a team of university researchers. We want to understand in detail what people like you think about social questions, in this case about abortion. We want to study the diversity of people’s beliefs, and whether algorithmic tools can help summarize and analyze these differing points of view.

What will I need to do and how long will the study last?
We will ask you 10 questions. We expect that you will be in this research study for less than an hour.

Compensation
Your pay will not depend on your opinions: all good-faith responses will get fully compensated, so please just write what you think. You may not use ChatGPT or other AI tools to write or edit your responses. We will award a $1 bonus if your submission satisfies all minimum length requirements across all questions.

Who will see your responses?
The data you provide will be immediately anonymized. We may later on publish this anonymous data. By continuing this survey, you agree to this use of your responses.

Who can I talk to?
If you have questions, concerns, complaints, or think the research has hurt you, you can contact the research team at gilirusak@g.harvard.edu.

We will begin by asking you 4 questions touching on specific parts of your opinion.

Background Questions

How often do think about abortion or discuss it with others? How does this topic make you feel?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think about abortion at least once a week. I feel very strongly that a woman should be able to choose what she does with her body and her fetus

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

text: The summary only supports abortion in extreme circumstances. I completely disagree with this position, largely because there is no way to fairly and ethically judge these cases, let alone in a timely enough manner to successfully abort afterwards.

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

text: This summary completely and totally captures my position on abortion. There is nothing meaningfully different about it, and nothing I would change.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

text: I think it should be legal. I think people have a right to decide for themselves what they want for their bodies. I also think criminalizing abortion puts so many people at risk, that it could never be framed as a pro-health stance.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I wouldn't say any particular life experience have influenced my beliefs, but rather seeing the adversity women around me have faced when it comes to abortion and hearing the venom and paradoxical rationalizations politicians come up with to deny people the right to something that is basic healthcare has radicalized me. I am a feminist and I believe women deserve equal rights with autonomy over their bodies, and I don't think the government should ever have the right to take that away.

question_text:
Background Questions

If not, I suppose maybe then it wouldn't be so appropriate but if the person wishes for the abortion, I don't think I can argue against that.

text: I wholeheartedly agree with everything this candidate is saying. I believe abortion is a personal decision between a person and their doctor, without government interference. I'm not sure there's much more I would need to add.

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

text: I don't believe adoption is a fully viable alternative to abortion. I think this also fails to capture the reality that many abortions occur because the pregnancy is no longer feasible, and carrying the fetus becomes a health risk to the person.

I also agree society should invest in sexual education and healthcare more, but abortion is healthcare.

text: I am fully in agreement with this summary. Abortion should be legal and accessible because people have the right to make decisions about their own bodies. How often do think about abortion or discuss it with others? How does this topic make you feel?

text: I think about abortion every now and then. As a young woman, I definitely don't want to have children at all and I'm serious about my decision. So I want to know about every birth control method out there so I can hopefully get sterilized and avoid possible pregnancy if can. I rarely discuss my pro-abortion views with my family because they already know I don't want kids and most of them don't feel that strongly about abortion either way. I'm passionate about the topic because a lot of anti-abortion people are hypocrites that say they care about children but then none of them adopt and or treat their own children horribly.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: Abortion should be legal. Rape victims, women who aren't ready for pregnancy, women who might die from pregnancy and any other case should be all within those circumstances. We live in a world where men will use pregnancy to trap women into an abusive relationship. Both the mother and the child cannot live happily and healthy in an environment like that.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: My main beliefs about abortion come from my leftist views and how hospitals treat pregnant black women. Pregnant black women are more likely to die during pregnancy due to the fault of the hospital. There are so many cases of black women in pain, crying out the whole time, and doctors and nurses ignoring it because of the racist myth that black people have a higher pain threshold. As a black woman myself, I am afraid of becoming pregnant because of how doctors treat black people in general. Everytime I go to the doctor or dentist, I make sure to tell them when I'm in pain.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: A situation where I'm unsure whether abortion is appropriate or not is when a young friend of mine suddenly gets pregnant. This could be 17 to 21 because some people decide whether or not they want to be a young mother. For some families, it's a normal thing to have babies young because it's traditional. However, becoming a young mother is practically throwing your life away because you cannot get a better job due to the lack of education in the long run. As much as I can voice my opinion on how they should probably abort, it's their decision at the end of the day. Of course, I'm saying this as long as the father is a healthy partner who loves them and supports their partner no matter what decision they choose. If this was any other case, I would be pro abortion and help my friend get away from the partner as soon as possible.

text: Society should make abortions legal no matter what the case is. Rape victims, women who might die during pregnancy, women who aren't ready for pregnancy, and more should be included in these circumstances. Having children can have permanent effects on both the mother and the child; it's in everyone's best interests to have fewer unwanted children and more living, breathing women in the world.

I also agree that society should give all women access to affordable healthcare, as birth control methods, menstruation products, abortion and more options are not cheap whatsoever. This person elevated my original viewpoint.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be illegal because it involves taking a human life, which I consider morally wrong. Society should focus on providing resources and support for pregnant women to encourage them to choose life. Adoption should be promoted as a viable alternative to abortion.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I disagree with their first statement. In the early stages of pregnancy, the "fetus" that's in the womb is not a human, it's just an egg. (I might use the wrong terminology because I do not know what the object is called for every stage of pregnancy). It's just like when a woman is starting her period and her body fertilizes the egg to ready her for pregnancy,but when she's not pregnant, she has her period because the egg is shedding its blood. It's not alive or considered human whatsoever. ALso, I disagree that adoption should be promoted as a viable alternative, some of the people that get pregnant either aren't ready for children or do not want children at all either adopted or otherwise. Some people are not fit to be parents. Everyone's circumstances are different. I do agree that society should provide resources and support for pregnant women because healthcare can be expensive and pregnancy can be stressful.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be restricted to certain circumstances, such as cases of rape, incest, or when the mother's life is at risk. This approach balances the rights of the unborn with the needs of women facing difficult situations. Society should provide support for women who carry their pregnancies to term, including healthcare and financial assistance.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree to their statement but abortion shouldn't be restricted whatsoever. Women who want to have lives of performing in their career, women who want to travel,  women who don't want children and more should be included as well. Some people aren't fit to be mothers. Some people aren't fit to be fathers. Not only that, having children can be extremely expensive and some people can't afford them.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree with everything they've said. Especially the comment about society supporting comprehensive sex education because the world lacks it. No matter what country you go to, women's sexuality and birth control methods are shunned because most societies are conservative and patriarchal. If more people knew the options of birth control, abortion would be a last resort. Even though I support abortions, I recognize that they are expensive and can be exhausting on the body. There are cases where women who get an abortion to avoid death, still pass away weeks after an abortion. These things do happen.

I think a woman’s right to choose should always be protected and I am horrified at what has been happening to that right in recent years.  Abortion is a healthcare decision that only a woman can make about her own body.  Forcing women to carry unwanted pregnancies to term is incredibly barbaraic.

Background Questions

text: I think abortion. Should be legal in all instances.  A child is an incredible responsibility and if a woman feels she is not ready for that reap she should not be forced to take that on.  Sometimes the decision is a financial one.  A woman feels she can not adequately support a child.  Or sometimes it is for the health of the woman or baby.  No one should get to choose but the woman.

.

Background Questions

How often do think about abortion or discuss it with others? How does this topic make you feel?

text:
I discuss it occasionally, usually just with my partner in the context of abortion bans. I am strongly pro-choice, as is my partner, and it scares me that the country is becoming more and more anti-choice. I worry about women who might have miscarriages or pregnancy complications but be refused any help because it's not deemed as "life threatening", even if it could still seriously harm them or make them sick, or cause unnecessary trauma. For example, a woman may be carrying a baby that has serious deformities that would mean it would not survive outside of the womb, but still be forced to carry to term a baby she knows isn't going to survive.


I personally am pro-choice and support the right to abortion up to the second trimester, except for medical complications.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think it should be legal with limits. The limit should just be no 3rd trimester, unless there's medical complications, maybe no second trimester either, unless medical complications. Always should be allowed in the 1st trimester for any reason whatsoever. For later in the pregnancy, maybe medical reasons, as I think you would be able to decide by then if you want to keep it or not.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: My abortion beliefs come from just thinking it out logically, having empathy for women who may find themselves in that situation, and from my own pregnancy scares. I've never been pregnant, but have worried I might be pregnant a few times due to my period being a little late. I knew I absolutely didn't want a baby, didn't want to be pregnant, and would have gotten an abortion if I had, in fact, been pregnant.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I'm not sure it's appropriate later in the pregnancy. I think later in the pregnancy, you've had enough time to figure out if you want to keep the baby or not. 3 months seems like enough time to me, so I'd say the 2nd trimester seems the most borderline. Unless there's medical complications, I feel a person has had enough time to figure out what they want to do by the 2nd trimester, though everyone is different.

question_text:

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: I support the right to abortion for any reason in the first trimester and the right to abortion for medical reasons, not just life-threatening medical reasons, for the rest of a pregnancy. I think there should be a federal law protecting the right to abortion within the first trimester, and maybe allow states to restrict from there. No one should be forced to have a baby, as having a baby drastically changes one's life way more than an abortion can, can cause much more trauma and hardship, and we shouldn't be making laws that are mainly stemming from religious beliefs.

That is very unfair. Abortion should always be allowed in cases of rape, incest, and life being at risk, but many other circumstances as well.

question_text:
Thank you for completing the survey!

Click below to register your survey completion with Prolific and return to their website.

Informed Consent

We are a team of university researchers. We want to understand in detail what people like you think about social questions, in this case about abortion. We want to study the diversity of people’s beliefs, and whether algorithmic tools can help summarize and analyze these differing points of view.

What will I need to do and how long will the study last?
We will ask you 10 questions. We expect that you will be in this research study for less than an hour.

Compensation
Your pay will not depend on your opinions: all good-faith responses will get fully compensated, so please just write what you think. You may not use ChatGPT or other AI tools to write or edit your responses. We will award a $1 bonus if your submission satisfies all minimum length requirements across all questions.

Who will see your responses?
The data you provide will be immediately anonymized. We may later on publish this anonymous data. By continuing this survey, you agree to this use of your responses.

Who can I talk to?
If you have questions, concerns, complaints, or think the research has hurt you, you can contact the research team at gilirusak@g.harvard.edu.

Part 1/3: Background Questions

We will begin by asking you 4 questions touching on specific parts of your opinion.

Background Questions

How often do think about abortion or discuss it with others? How does this topic make you feel?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: Prior to the Supreme Court overturning Roe, abortion wasn't often a topic of conversation. Although virtually everyone I know is pro-choice, many of those people are personally opposed to having an abortion themselves, but do not feel it necessary to police the decisions of others. Since the SCOTUS decision abortion is a more common topic, along with the other controversial decisions the Court has made. I believe it was Hillary Clinton who said the goal should be to make abortion legal, safe, and rare. I totally agree.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: Abortion is a medical procedure that should be legal, and the decision to undergo that procedure should be solely that of the pregnant woman. Of course there should be time limits on the procedure, based on fetal viability, but beyond that it should be a private choice. It's the height of hypocrisy that laws controlling women's bodies should be written and enforced by men.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: As a young man, I had two girlfriends who got pregnant, and both terminated their pregnancies by abortion. In both cases it was a wrenching and painful decision, but it was also a private, personal decision. I regret my youthful irresponsibility, but I don't believe those two women's lives (or mine) would have been improved be carrying those pregnancies to term. On a more global scale, I believe all women should have the freedom to make choices regarding their own health and bodies - just as men do.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: Prior to fetal viability, I think abortion is entirely appropriate if that's the choice of the pregnant woman. It's her body and her business. The only ambiguity I can imagine would be in cases of near-viability - and even then, I think the decision still has to come from the woman, not from a judge or politician.

question_text:
Part 2/3: Your Position

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: Unplanned pregnancies, rape and incest, and birth defects... all of these are unanticipated events that can happen to any woman of childbearing age. Just as we provide medical assistance for injuries and disease, we should feel a moral obligation to assist women with unwanted pregnancies by providing legal, medically safe abortions upon request. It's entirely reasonable to restrict the procedure to the time period prior to fetal viability, but beyond that we should allow women the unrestricted right to make their own decisions about their own body.

question_text:
Part 3/3: Candidate Summaries

To help researchers and policymakers understand public opinion on abortion, we will condense the survey responses into a short summary. We will now present 5 candidate summaries to you, and your task is to rate to what extent they would capture your point of view.

An ideal summary should

  1. perfectly capture all your thoughts and feelings on abortion,
  2. include the reasoning behind your opinion, and
  3. be concrete and actionable.

Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be a personal decision between a woman and her doctor, without government interference. Each situation is unique, and women should have the autonomy to make the best choice for themselves and their families. Society should ensure that all women have access to affordable healthcare, including reproductive services.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I completely agree with this summary, although I believe it lacks the necessary controls to be effectively implemented. No one wants abortion to be a substitute for birth control, and no one wants viable babies to be terminated. Abortion should be freely available as described above, only up to the point of fetal viability.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be legal and accessible because women have the right to make decisions about their own bodies. Access to safe abortions is crucial for protecting women's health and well-being. Society should support comprehensive sex education and contraception to reduce the need for abortions.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: Again, completely agree with this summary. I particularly appreciate the additional insight shown by the inclusion of education and contraception. But once again, I believe abortion needs to have practical limits based on fetal viability.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be illegal because it involves taking a human life, which I consider morally wrong. Society should focus on providing resources and support for pregnant women to encourage them to choose life. Adoption should be promoted as a viable alternative to abortion.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: Taking a human life is morally wrong, yet we as a society have rationalized various scenarios under which it is acceptable (capital punishment, war, self-defense). Furthermore, a non-viable fetus is not a human life - it's only a collection of cells, a potential human life. Adoption and other resources are always available and should continue to be a consideration, but not to the exclusion of abortion.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be restricted to certain circumstances, such as cases of rape, incest, or when the mother's life is at risk. This approach balances the rights of the unborn with the needs of women facing difficult situations. Society should provide support for women who carry their pregnancies to term, including healthcare and financial assistance.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: The inconsistency of this position actually baffles me. If the unborn have rights, then the source of the conception shouldn't matter. On the other hand, if certain "difficult situations" justify abortion, then who's to say what situations fall on one side or the other of the line? This argument is a cop-out for those not willing to fully interrogate their own viewpoint on the issue.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be allowed in the first trimester but restricted afterward unless there are exceptional circumstances. This policy respects a woman's right to choose while recognizing the increasing moral considerations as the pregnancy progresses. Society should invest in education and healthcare to prevent unwanted pregnancies and support women through their reproductive choices.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text:
This summary comes the closest to my personal belief. My only issue is the ambiguity around "exceptional circumstances", which I assume would need to be legally defined (and thereby run into who knows what sort of challenges). Also, I'm not clear on the current limits on fetal viability, so rather than a hard stop at second trimester, I'd prefer a more medically-endorsed deadline. 

But in total this summary balances women's rights to autonomy with necessary limits and alternative solutions.

You may not use ChatGPT or other AI tools to write or edit your responses. We will award a $1 bonus if your submission satisfies all minimum length requirements across all questions.

Who will see your responses?
The data you provide will be immediately anonymized. We may later on publish this anonymous data. By continuing this survey, you agree to this use of your responses.

Who can I talk to?
If you have questions, concerns, complaints, or think the research has hurt you, you can contact the research team at gilirusak@g.harvard.edu.

Part 1/3: Background Questions

We will begin by asking you 4 questions touching on specific parts of your opinion.

Background Questions

How often do think about abortion or discuss it with others? How does this topic make you feel?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I don't particularly discuss it with other people because I generally assume most of my family members and people from my friend group(s) have the same opinion as me. I usually think about it more when something huge happens (i.e., laws are passed that ban or restrict it, safeguards are put up in states to protect abortion rights, etc.) but I wouldn't say it's one of the key things I think about. I personally have always felt that it's not my place to critique a person for getting an abortion; it doesn't impact me because I'm not the one doing it. If I had a partner who needed (or wanted) an abortion, I'm not the one carrying the baby so I shouldn't have that much of a say on the matter. If it's beneficial to the person's mental or physical health, they should just be allowed to do it.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: It should be legal with no restrictions or limitations. There are no circumstances that change my answer. If a woman gets pregnant on accident and just doesn't feel like she's in a position to raise a child, that's a good enough reason to abort a baby.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: To be honest, I just feel like it seems "right" to support free access to abortion. When I was in middle and high school, we often read stories about women who had to use coat hangers to abort their babies. The amount of pain, suffering, and death that they went through just because abortions weren't legal was miserable to hear about. I understand some of the pro-life talking points, but it just doesn't make sense to try and revert back to those dangerous methods because they want a baby to potentially be born. One of the pro-life points they always make is that a baby can be put up for adoption, with some pro-life people arguing that they would take and raise a baby if a pro-choice person had it, or something like that. But then the adoption/foster care centers are still always full. That's foolish. So I guess a lot of my views come from what I learned in school and from seeing logical fallacies with pro-life people's arguments.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I do think that the later an abortion happens, the more "iffy" it gets. I'm not too sure of pregnancy timelines but obviously it seems much simpler to abort a baby closer to when it's smaller; I don't know how it works when the baby is big and about to come out. Then again, it's my understanding that late abortions are mostly only done when there's serious potential for death for either the mother or baby with limited options. It's also kind of complicated when people abort a baby just because they're sure it might be seriously disabled. On one hand, I support people who recognize they're not capable of raising a special needs child, but it's also a bit sad to think they were aborted solely due to a potential disability. I guess it depends on the rationale for both of those scenarios.

question_text:
Part 2/3: Your Position

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: In my opinion, we should work to legalize and protect abortion rights for everyone who needs or wants an abortion. Throughout history, we have seen how dangerous abortions can be if done without medical assistance; revoking abortion rights leads to higher death rates. The person carrying the baby should be the only person who has a say in whether they get an abortion or not; governments should not be involved.

question_text:
Part 3/3: Candidate Summaries

To help researchers and policymakers understand public opinion on abortion, we will condense the survey responses into a short summary. We will now present 5 candidate summaries to you, and your task is to rate to what extent they would capture your point of view.

An ideal summary should

  1. perfectly capture all your thoughts and feelings on abortion,
  2. include the reasoning behind your opinion, and
  3. be concrete and actionable.

Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be illegal because it involves taking a human life, which I consider morally wrong. Society should focus on providing resources and support for pregnant women to encourage them to choose life. Adoption should be promoted as a viable alternative to abortion.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text:
I agree that adoption could be promoted as a better option, but we need to do drastic overhauls regarding the adoption process, adoption systems, and general foster care. With the amount of foster family abuse I hear about (people adopting just to get money for it), we need much better adoption rules and vetting. If this candidate elaborated on their plans to improve the adoption system in this country, our viewpoints might overlap there.

I disagree that abortion is taking a human life; in a majority of cases, the "baby" hasn't even developed enough to be called a baby. I also disagree with the part the candidate mentioned about providing support and resources. While this sounds good on paper, I've seen quite a lot of "resources" given to people considering an abortion that just works to guilt people into keeping the baby which is unhelpful.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be a personal decision between a woman and her doctor, without government interference. Each situation is unique, and women should have the autonomy to make the best choice for themselves and their families. Society should ensure that all women have access to affordable healthcare, including reproductive services.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree with each point the candidate made here. The major point that we both agree on is that it's solely up to whoever is carrying the baby and whoever their healthcare provider is. The point about affordable healthcare is another good point. Pro-choice people like to argue that abortions should be illegal, but don't want to provide funds to expand or improve reproductive healthcare.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be allowed in the first trimester but restricted afterward unless there are exceptional circumstances. This policy respects a woman's right to choose while recognizing the increasing moral considerations as the pregnancy progresses. Society should invest in education and healthcare to prevent unwanted pregnancies and support women through their reproductive choices.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree that we should invest in education and healthcare to reduce the amount of accidental pregnancies, but it's worth noting that a lot of unwanted pregnancies come from rape or incest rather than just poor decisions. The first trimester is ~the first 3 months or so of pregnancy. I think that's when most people get abortions done on average, but there are rare cases where a person can just not know they're pregnant until much later. Therefore, I get what the person is saying, but I don't think it's a wise idea to just restrict abortions at a certain time.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be legal and accessible because women have the right to make decisions about their own bodies. Access to safe abortions is crucial for protecting women's health and well-being. Society should support comprehensive sex education and contraception to reduce the need for abortions.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree with all the points here. I think that more information about the kind of sex education or contraception the candidate means would be good, though. As I've said before, there's a lot of material that solely serves to guilt potential mothers into keeping the baby; neutral, health-oriented abortion materials should be provided instead. Overall, some more concrete information about the resources or expanding access would be reflective of my particular viewpoint.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be restricted to certain circumstances, such as cases of rape, incest, or when the mother's life is at risk. This approach balances the rights of the unborn with the needs of women facing difficult situations. Society should provide support for women who carry their pregnancies to term, including healthcare and financial assistance.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text:
I agree that we should provide support for women carrying to term; many abortions are done due to financial issues, potential health issues, or both. However, that support should continue beyond when the baby is born. It doesn't make sense to only provide assistance when the baby isn't born yet, then strip the mother away from help that would prevent her from getting an abortion.

I disagree with most of the other information. There shouldn't be restrictions with exceptions. I've seen people with "certain circumstances" have to travel to other states to get an abortion because the judge or whatever didn't sign off on their circumstance. We shouldn't be telling another person that their abortion needs are inferior to another person's. Furthermore, it's weird to place an unborn person's rights on the same level as a living human being; the first 'person' doesn't even exist yet.
