We will begin by asking you 4 questions touching on specific parts of your opinion.

Background Questions

How often do think about abortion or discuss it with others? How does this topic make you feel?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: Honestly, I know what my stance is so I don't have to think much about it. I probably don't ever truly think about it until I hear or read a headline. I'm at a point in my life where I won't be having any more children (I have one) & the outcome of the abortion rights issue doesn't hit home as hard. Nevertheless, I believe in the right to choose.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think it should hands-down be legal. I'm not in a position to tell women what to do with their bodies (I'm a male) & there are Bonafide health reasons to have an abortion (not to mention, rape cases as well). My perspective is possibly unique because I'm a nurse by trade & see denying abortion as denying healthcare just because of your religious viewpoints or personal feelings.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: As stated, I'm a nurse by trade. I know about healthcare concerns such as etopic pregnancies. Prior to becoming a nurse I thought the same way. I learned about the unfortunate subject of rape early in my life & could never fathom having to raise a child in such a situation. I just figure, make the option available; if they decide not to use it, ok. If they do, by all means, that's your decision.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I recently learned that some of our good friends are going to be welcoming their third child. Unfortunately, the third child wasn't planned. They're financially ok as a family, but the new addition is going to make things more rough. Perhaps if they were to tell me, "I just don't feel like having another" & didn't provide any context, then I would say that abortion isn't right (but again, it's not my choice).

question_text:
Part 2/3: Your Position

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: I believe abortion should be made legal for many reasons, including etopic pregnancies & situations involving rape. In nursing school I learned that etopic pregnancies can be highly dangerous to both the mother & child & it could lead to choosing between one life or another. For the situations involving rape, it seems to me that it often involves underage girls which isn't developmentally good for either the mother or child.

text: I don't think abortion should be restricted at all. If a woman wants to have one, by all means, make the decision with your partner. If she has one "just because" then it will be on her/their conscience.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think it should be illegal in most cases. As a conservative, I strongly believe that every life should be allowed a chance to live. Moreover, my religious beliefs are against ending the life of an unborn, voiceless, and innocent being.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: My views on abortion are founded on a mix of personal values and my religious beliefs. I was much influenced by my faith, where the issue of the sanctity of life matters. and, personal experiences and reflection upon the value of life have deeply influenced me to stick with these views.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: One situation when I really do feel that the appropriateness of abortion may not be so crystal clear is when a pregnancy has serious health risks to the mother, like when it is going to cause serious complications or even result in death if not terminated. This is borderline because it weighs between the life and well-being of the mother with the potential that exists in the unborn child; hence, it is quite deep and morally challenging.

question_text:
Part 2/3: Your Position

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: I am of the opinion that, in most cases, abortion should be illegal. For me, the chance to live is very dear; it would be morally wrong to take away the life of an unborn, voiceless, innocent being. Society should give precedence to the protection of these lives and uphold laws that speak of the sanctity of life. Exceptions should only be made when the mother's life is considerably at risk, but these need to be reviewed in a proper balancing of ethical considerations.

It just allows people to still do wrong with the preconception that there is an acceptable time frame to rectify if you know what I mean.

This topic makes me feel uncomfortable and sad, having mixed emotions but a solid moral stance. I have empathy and compassion for those I am close to who have had abortions under tough circumstances and disgust for those who have had abortions for selfish reasons.

question_text:

text: I think abortion should be illegal in most circumstances. I feel the only circumstances in which abortion should be legal is when the pregnancy is dangerous to the mother, meaning risk or certain death for the mother, or if the quality of life of the baby would be such that it would suffer inhumanely.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: My beliefs about abortion come from my moral values. Believing in God, I feel it is not our right to decide who lives and who dies, especially when it comes to the life of a child, unable to defend themselves. Many particular personal and non-personal life experiences have influenced these beliefs, but I feel that anyone with any common sense or a conscious would feel the same way.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: A situation where I am not sure if abortion would be appropriate or not would be in the case of the baby's condition. This kind of situation makes abortion borderline because, on the one hand, one would think that it would be unfair and inhumane to carry a baby to full term knowing the quality of life it would have would be extremely negative, and on the other hand considering that a life is a life no matter the quality and we do not get to decide their fate despite any/all of these factors. There is a very thin line between morality and humanity, quality of life and life period.

text: My overall position on abortion is that it should be 99% illegal, except for extenuating circumstances, to be solely determined by a medically professional diagnosis. I think society should deal with abortions on a case-to-case basis, where the sole deciding factor would be the quality of life for the child. Severe deformities, mortal conditions, the child's expectancy of living and suffering inhumanely, and killing the mother in the process being the only reasons to legally terminate.

I agree with most of it, abortion should be restricted unless there are exceptional circumstances, but I disagree that it should be allowed in the first trimester unless there are exceptional circumstances. Upon conception, once there is a heartbeat, I feel all bets should be off, aside from the extenuating circumstances. I also totally agree that society should invest in education and healthcare to prevent unwanted pregnancies and support women through their reproductive choices.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be a personal decision between a woman and her doctor, without government interference. Each situation is unique, and women should have the autonomy to make the best choice for themselves and their families. Society should ensure that all women have access to affordable healthcare, including reproductive services.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: This summary moderately captures my viewpoint on abortion. I agree that each situation is unique, but that unless the circumstance is death to mother or child, or poor inhumane quality of life, there should be no autonomy to make this choice for this child. I also agree that society should ensure that all women have access to affordable healthcare, including reproductive services. This summary needs to include access to additional services such as counseling, resources, and adoption options for those who feel they cannot take care of the baby after birth, but in no way should be an option before that. I think government interference would not be ideal, but necessary for those who feel they do not need to comply and would look for ways to get around carrying an unwanted pregnancy to term.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be illegal because it involves taking a human life, which I consider morally wrong. Society should focus on providing resources and support for pregnant women to encourage them to choose life. Adoption should be promoted as a viable alternative to abortion.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: This summary totally captures my viewpoint on abortion.  I agree with all parts and feel it matches my moral views on the subject.

question_text:

Here is a possible summary:

This approach balances the rights of the unborn with the needs of women facing difficult situations. Society should provide support for women who carry their pregnancies to term, including healthcare and financial assistance.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think this summary captures my viewpoint on abortion somewhat. I agree it should be restricted to certain circumstances such as when the mother's life is at risk, but not in cases of rape or incest. I feel in those circumstances, resources and adoption services should be made available to ensure the baby is carried to full term, safely, and given a chance to live a life not asked for. With the exception of the mother or baby's life being at risk, I feel there could never be a balance in the rights of the unborn with the needs of women facing difficult decisions. I feel it is a double standard where the same women would not find it acceptable for anyone to decide their life, so why and how should they be able to make that same decision for someone else.

Thank you for completing the survey!

Click below to register your survey completion with Prolific and return to their website.

Informed Consent

We are a team of university researchers. We want to understand in detail what people like you think about social questions, in this case about abortion. We want to study the diversity of people’s beliefs, and whether algorithmic tools can help summarize and analyze these differing points of view.

What will I need to do and how long will the study last?
We will ask you 10 questions. We expect that you will be in this research study for less than an hour.

Compensation
Your pay will not depend on your opinions: all good-faith responses will get fully compensated, so please just write what you think. You may not use ChatGPT or other AI tools to write or edit your responses. We will award a $1 bonus if your submission satisfies all minimum length requirements across all questions.

Who will see your responses?
The data you provide will be immediately anonymized. We may later on publish this anonymous data. By continuing this survey, you agree to this use of your responses.

Who can I talk to?
If you have questions, concerns, complaints, or think the research has hurt you, you can contact the research team at gilirusak@g.harvard.edu.

Background Questions

How often do think about abortion or discuss it with others? How does this topic make you feel?

text: I only really think about it when it's brought up in the news. I don't much care for women's rights being politicized.

question_text:
Background Questions

text: Abortion should be legal full stop. There is no compromise on this topic for me.

question_text:

text: No particular life experience influenced my belief. I simply don't think any argument against the concept is convincing enough.

text: I guess I would say that abortion post birth would be inappropriate. But that's probably just murder.

question_text:

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: Abortion should be legal in it's entirety, with no compromise. "Pregnancy regret" isn't even the only reason to have an abortion. A woman might have some sort of health condition that would put her in danger if she continues with a pregnancy.

question_text:

  3. be concrete and actionable.

Access to safe abortions is crucial for protecting women's health and well-being. Society should support comprehensive sex education and contraception to reduce the need for abortions.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree with this in it's entirety. The only argument I see against abortion is religious based, which is abstract at best.

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree that we should provide support for women who carry their pregnancies to term, but this person is forgetting that abortion is a form of healthcare. If you outlaw any form of abortion, you provide a slippery slope for outlawing all of abortion, unnecessarily putting lives at risk.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be allowed in the first trimester but restricted afterward unless there are exceptional circumstances. This policy respects a woman's right to choose while recognizing the increasing moral considerations as the pregnancy progresses. Society should invest in education and healthcare to prevent unwanted pregnancies and support women through their reproductive choices.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree that sexual education is essential in avoiding unwanted pregnancies, but as I said before, you cannot restrict one type of abortion without providing a slippery slope for outlawing all forms of abortion. To believe otherwise is naive.

text: Abortion should be fully available to women that choose to have the abortion, and the father does not contest the abortion. I also disagree with the statement about society needing to ensure that all women have access to affordable healthcare. It is not societies job to cover the financial responsibility of women that negligently get pregnant. The candidate should add that women need to pay for their own carelessness in getting pregnant just as people have to pay speeding tickets when they carelessly speed in their car.

I disagree that support women through their reproductive choice, because unless rape or incest is involved then the women chose to not use protection and got pregnant. I would like to see that candidate add that women need to be financially accountable for an abortion or healthcare if it is required.

text: I disagree with the candidate saying abortion should be restricted to certain circumstances. Unless society is prepared to pay for an unwanted baby from birth to the grave then I don't perceive the choice as a societal choice. The candidate says society should provide support for women who carry their pregnancies to term including healthcare and financial assistance, and I agree that society should support women but not financially because that is part of being an adult paying your own bills in life. I would like to hear the candidate say that society should support women that carry their child to term, and support unwanted children throughout their lives if the mother is forced to carry an unwanted child to term.

Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be a personal decision between a woman and her doctor, without government interference. Each situation is unique, and women should have the autonomy to make the best choice for themselves and their families. Society should ensure that all women have access to affordable healthcare, including reproductive services.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree. the government has no place in bodily autonomy, especially when it comes to reproductive care. society should not only provide but encourage the use of reproductive services.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be restricted to certain circumstances, such as cases of rape, incest, or when the mother's life is at risk. This approach balances the rights of the unborn with the needs of women facing difficult situations. Society should provide support for women who carry their pregnancies to term, including healthcare and financial assistance.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I disagree with this completely. it is unethical to give more rights to an unborn baby than to it's parent. a society that provides support to people who carry to term, and not to those who are for any reason unable to care for a child, is sickening to me. this view is dangerous.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be illegal because it involves taking a human life, which I consider morally wrong. Society should focus on providing resources and support for pregnant women to encourage them to choose life. Adoption should be promoted as a viable alternative to abortion.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I disagree completely. an unborn baby is not yet a human life, and holding this view point is damaging to those who are not able to care for a child, such as the mentally ill, disabled, or people facing poverty. pregnancy is hard on the body and mind, and offering adoption relieves no one of that burden. there are already so many children in foster care that do not have homes, and banning abortion will only cause more suffering and over crowding in these kinds of places.

Part 1/3: Background Questions

We will begin by asking you 4 questions touching on specific parts of your opinion.

Background Questions

How often do think about abortion or discuss it with others? How does this topic make you feel?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: Very rarely do I think about it other than looking on the past when I girlfriend of mine had one. I feel grateful that there was the option for her to have one. My life would be a whole lot different now and probably not for the better. I strongly support a woman's right to choose what to do with her body. As for discussing it, that never happens and if it does it is in passing as a more encompassing thing of supporting equality and woman's rights.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: Legal up to a certain trimester. At a certain point in development we can no longer consider it a fetus, but a human being with rights even though it cannot defend itself.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think it stems from just the belief that you are in control of your own person and body as a male. If I want to do something to my body, it is my body and I should be able to do it. I mean there are limits like amputating a limb or something for no reason other than aesthetics. A person should dictate how they want their life to play out obviously minimizing the harm done to others.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I do not think there is a situation where it is not appropriate other than after the third trimester. Even then it could be appropriate if the pregnancy/baby is endangering the life of the mother. I fully believe in bodily autonomy.

question_text:
Part 2/3: Your Position

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: Society should allow abortions up to the third trimester of pregnancy as outlined in Roe v. Wade. A woman has every right to govern what to do with her body when with respect to human life, that is both hers and the baby's. Science has shown consciousness is in place by the third trimester and that is what should govern whether something is its own person at the onset of life.

question_text:
Part 3/3: Candidate Summaries

To help researchers and policymakers understand public opinion on abortion, we will condense the survey responses into a short summary. We will now present 5 candidate summaries to you, and your task is to rate to what extent they would capture your point of view.

An ideal summary should

  1. perfectly capture all your thoughts and feelings on abortion,
  2. include the reasoning behind your opinion, and
  3. be concrete and actionable.

Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be allowed in the first trimester but restricted afterward unless there are exceptional circumstances. This policy respects a woman's right to choose while recognizing the increasing moral considerations as the pregnancy progresses. Society should invest in education and healthcare to prevent unwanted pregnancies and support women through their reproductive choices.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: The only thing in agreement is that women should have reproductive choice but it fails in all other aspects. The person draws an imaginary line at first trimester that has no scientific backing whatsoever. I agree that there should be exceptions made but their cutoff time is arbitrary.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

text: They allow for abortions throughout the whole pregnancy it seems. They made no mention to delineate the cutoff. Their premise for allowing abortions is spot on.

text: I have qualms about the doctor part. That just should be in regards to the general health of having the procedure. Government interference as well. text: This person is totally against abortion. Nothing said agrees with what I believe. This person would probably need to be "blessed" with a special needs child or have someone close to them have a baby born out of rape or incest to change their opinion. And I suspect if that happened their viewpoint would only move slightly and nothing more could be done to sway it further.

question_text:
Background Questions

text: I think abortion should be illegal.  Simply put killing another human individual is illegal and I believe a baby in utero has already qualified itself as a human person even if they haven't been born and processed as a legal person yet.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I'm Catholic so I've grown up in a pro-life culture, however, I used to think pro-choice is an option given that pregnancy is a physical and financial burden.  The more I thought about the baby the more I couldn't deny abortion is simply killing a life.  So, if people want a choice of not having a baby, they can just abstain from sex during their fertile window.

question_text:
Background Questions

text: This depends on what people consider abortion to be.  For example, I don't think aborting a dead fetus or an unviable embryo is abortion.  There are some cases where I think if a pregnancy is high risk to mother and child it is debatable.  Largely though, I believe abortion inappropriate in all cases.

question_text:

text: I believe abortion should be illegal plain and simple even in the case of rape, we should have greater consequences for the rapist, but not end a life.  In regards to the pro-choice viewpoints, we should teach both young men and women better about a woman's fertile cycle; using natural family planning is by abstaining from sex during a woman's fertile window has the same percentage of efficacy as the pill and other contraceptives.  Abstaining from sex during a woman's fertile period is not the same as saving sex until marriage, so regardless of people's sexual morality it should be taught.

It's absolutely ridiculous and shouldn't ever have become an issue in the first place

  3. be concrete and actionable.

Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be allowed in the first trimester but restricted afterward unless there are exceptional circumstances. This policy respects a woman's right to choose while recognizing the increasing moral considerations as the pregnancy progresses. Society should invest in education and healthcare to prevent unwanted pregnancies and support women through their reproductive choices.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree about almost all that was said here. I disagree with only being allowed during the first trimester because for a decent chunk of that there's a chance the mother doesn't even know she's pregnant.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

“I think abortion should be a personal decision between a woman and her doctor, without government interference. How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: This is a perfect summary on it. It should be no one else's business except for the woman and her doctor. The government has no right to step in on anything like this and should only be around to help ease the burden of something like this.

text: I disagree that it should be restricted at all. This speaks of "the rights of the unborn" but if we're talking about times that an abortion could legally happen already then I can't even say that the thing is a person yet. There are no rights for something that cannot think or feel.

text: This summary is also perfect. As a society we should be trying to reduce the need for abortions with sex education and contraception options. Background Questions

text: I think that abortion should be illegal after 4 weeks unless the life of the mother is in danger. I would prefer it be illegal except for safety concerns, but I don't think society can properly handle that yet. Illegalizing abortion will not stop abortions currently, but maybe we can reduce abortions for convenience.

There is an industry that deals in fetal tissue. I think this society disregards the lives of children at all stages of development, even pre-birth.

I would like more discretion applied to limiting what development of pre-birth humans are not allowed to terminated.

text: I think abortion should be treated at best, a necessary evil. The fact that it is celebrated by aspects of our society is horrific. We should make efforts to limit abortion by addressing the scenarios that make people seek it out and continue those efforts until we can eliminate it as much as we can, while safeguarding the life of the mother.

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: Abortion it a difficult topic to talk about. But being a Christian man, I think abortion should be illegal.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: Well, as I mentioned in the previous question. I am a Christian man. And, I don't believe that any child (that God has created) should be killed by having an abortion.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: Being a Christian man, I believe it is not appropriate at all. Maybe, God has a purpose for that child's life.

question_text:
Part 2/3: Your Position

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: I believe society will never 'deal' with abortion because people are people and they have different opinions. As I have already mentioned... I am a Christian man, and I don't believe it is appropriate to have an abortion. Because God may have a purpose of the child's life.

question_text:
Part 3/3: Candidate Summaries

To help researchers and policymakers understand public opinion on abortion, we will condense the survey responses into a short summary. We will now present 5 candidate summaries to you, and your task is to rate to what extent they would capture your point of view.

An ideal summary should

  1. perfectly capture all your thoughts and feelings on abortion,
  2. include the reasoning behind your opinion, and
  3. be concrete and actionable.

Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be illegal because it involves taking a human life, which I consider morally wrong. Society should focus on providing resources and support for pregnant women to encourage them to choose life. Adoption should be promoted as a viable alternative to abortion.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree with the whole viewpoint.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be a personal decision between a woman and her doctor, without government interference. Each situation is unique, and women should have the autonomy to make the best choice for themselves and their families. Society should ensure that all women have access to affordable healthcare, including reproductive services.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I disagree with the whole viewpoint.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be legal and accessible because women have the right to make decisions about their own bodies. Access to safe abortions is crucial for protecting women's health and well-being. Society should support comprehensive sex education and contraception to reduce the need for abortions.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I disagree with the first part, and the second part, but agree with the last part.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be allowed in the first trimester but restricted afterward unless there are exceptional circumstances. This policy respects a woman's right to choose while recognizing the increasing moral considerations as the pregnancy progresses. Society should invest in education and healthcare to prevent unwanted pregnancies and support women through their reproductive choices.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think that abortion should be restricted in all circumstances.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be restricted to certain circumstances, such as cases of rape, incest, or when the mother's life is at risk. This approach balances the rights of the unborn with the needs of women facing difficult situations. Society should provide support for women who carry their pregnancies to term, including healthcare and financial assistance.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think that abortion should be restricted in all circumstances.

question_text:
Thank you for completing the survey!

Click below to register your survey completion with Prolific and return to their website.

Informed Consent

We are a team of university researchers. We want to understand in detail what people like you think about social questions, in this case about abortion. We want to study the diversity of people’s beliefs, and whether algorithmic tools can help summarize and analyze these differing points of view.

What will I need to do and how long will the study last?
We will ask you 10 questions. We expect that you will be in this research study for less than an hour.

Compensation
Your pay will not depend on your opinions: all good-faith responses will get fully compensated, so please just write what you think. You may not use ChatGPT or other AI tools to write or edit your responses. We will award a $1 bonus if your submission satisfies all minimum length requirements across all questions.

Who will see your responses?
The data you provide will be immediately anonymized. We may later on publish this anonymous data. By continuing this survey, you agree to this use of your responses.

Who can I talk to?
If you have questions, concerns, complaints, or think the research has hurt you, you can contact the research team at gilirusak@g.harvard.edu.

text: I often think about the issue of abortion but rarely engage in conversation with others about it as it can be a touchy subject. But, if I'm comfortable with dialogue and debate with someone, I'm happy to be honest about my views. The topic itself doesn't make me uncomfortable whereas discussing it with others has the possibility of being fraught with emotion negatively.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: Abortion should be legal but there should be limits as I don't think a late term abortion is morally right. Having said that, I understand the difficulty in being either too liberal or too conservative on the topic, there needs to be a rational balance which is often missing in the debate. Obviously, if the mother's life is in danger or in the cases of rape/incest, there should always be a legal option as it would be beyond cruel to inflict an unnecessary problem in someone's life.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I'm influenced by the idea that all life is sacred, but I also recognize not everything is cut and dry and situations have nuances. I've had close friends who have talked openly about their abortions, none of them are particularly proud of it but accept that it was the right thing for them to do at the time. I have a hard time judging someone for this, so I tend to not judge people in this circumstance.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: The only situation I can wrap my head around would be wondering if abortion is appropriate for someone who doesn't respect what the procedure actually is, someone who treats it the way they would contraceptives or think of abortion as simply another form of birth control. In that circumstance, I would question whether abortion is an appropriate procedure.

question_text:

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: My position is that abortion should always be legal and available for those who need such a procedure. We've seen what making it illegal does, the time and expense and danger of an illegal operation for something that should really be nobody else's business, the epitome of a personal matter. However, there need to be limits so that the availability isn't corrupted by those who don't have a basic respect for the seriousness of abortion.

Part 1/3: Background Questions

We will begin by asking you 4 questions touching on specific parts of your opinion.

Background Questions

How often do think about abortion or discuss it with others? How does this topic make you feel?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think about abortion (as a political issue more than a personal one) frequently. I feel stressed when I think about restrictions placed on reproductive freedom and motivated to support candidates and organizations committed to improving abortion access. I discuss it semi-frequently for work and with friends.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: Abortion should absolutely be legal under all circumstances. It's a myth to say women are carrying babies for months and then deciding not to give birth—late term abortions are the result of health issues. Abortion is fundamental to women's freedom.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: My beliefs on abortion come from my fundamental beliefs in human rights and dignity. I have never had an abortion, but I know people who have, and the choice allowed them to live their lives freely and responsibly.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: The only scenario that gives me pause is a late-term abortion for a previously wanted and currently healthy pregnancy. But I still believe that a woman's right to choose supersedes the rights of an unborn fetus, and I believe abortion is preferable to bringing an unwanted child into the world.

question_text:
Part 2/3: Your Position

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: Abortion should be legal and without restrictions. Fundamentally, women should have total autonomy over their bodies and the trajectories of their lives, and any law that forces them to carry a child against their will impedes on this—and threatens freedom more broadly. Most women who have abortions are already mothers, and so it's not as if women who have abortions do so recklessly or carelessly: they make calculated, careful decisions that they've determined are best and most responsible for themselves and their families.

question_text:
Part 3/3: Candidate Summaries

To help researchers and policymakers understand public opinion on abortion, we will condense the survey responses into a short summary. We will now present 5 candidate summaries to you, and your task is to rate to what extent they would capture your point of view.

An ideal summary should

  1. perfectly capture all your thoughts and feelings on abortion,
  2. include the reasoning behind your opinion, and
  3. be concrete and actionable.

Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be allowed in the first trimester but restricted afterward unless there are exceptional circumstances. This policy respects a woman's right to choose while recognizing the increasing moral considerations as the pregnancy progresses. Society should invest in education and healthcare to prevent unwanted pregnancies and support women through their reproductive choices.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I largely agree with this candidate's position, though I would want clarification on what would qualify as "exceptional circumstances." I think as long as that is broadly defined, I'd be in total agreement with this policy, since the vast majority of late-term abortions are indeed for pregnancies suffering from exceptional health circumstances.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be illegal because it involves taking a human life, which I consider morally wrong. Society should focus on providing resources and support for pregnant women to encourage them to choose life. Adoption should be promoted as a viable alternative to abortion.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: This candidate's view is completely at odds with my views on abortion. It entirely ignores a woman's right to choose, and gives equal weight to the experiences of a woman and an unborn fetus, which I do not think is accurate. Women should be given information to empower them to make the best decision for themselves—not just the decision that will preserve a fetus's life. Adoption is not a viable alternative; thousands of children go un-adopted every year and there are tremendous flaws in the foster care system.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be restricted to certain circumstances, such as cases of rape, incest, or when the mother's life is at risk. This approach balances the rights of the unborn with the needs of women facing difficult situations. Society should provide support for women who carry their pregnancies to term, including healthcare and financial assistance.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: This view places too much emphasis on the "rights of the unborn" at the expense of the rights of a woman. There are many valid reasons to not want to carry a pregnancy to term outside of the three cases listed—including a terminal diagnosis for a fetus, difficult life circumstances, or mental health challenges for the mother.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be legal and accessible because women have the right to make decisions about their own bodies. Access to safe abortions is crucial for protecting women's health and well-being. Society should support comprehensive sex education and contraception to reduce the need for abortions.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: This candidate's views match mine exactly. Abortion is a matter of freedom and education, and it's essential that women both learn about all the options available to them, and then in turn have the legal ability to choose between them. But, of course, there are many things that should come before abortion access, and we should prevent as many unwanted pregnancies as possible.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be a personal decision between a woman and her doctor, without government interference. Each situation is unique, and women should have the autonomy to make the best choice for themselves and their families. Society should ensure that all women have access to affordable healthcare, including reproductive services.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: This candidate comes at the issue from a different perspective than I do, but we land in the same place. I think less about the role of the government—though I agree with this candidate—but I fundamentally agree that women deserve autonomy and freedom to make the right decisions for themselves.

Click below to register your survey completion with Prolific and return to their website.

Informed Consent

We are a team of university researchers. We want to understand in detail what people like you think about social questions, in this case about abortion. We want to study the diversity of people’s beliefs, and whether algorithmic tools can help summarize and analyze these differing points of view.

What will I need to do and how long will the study last?
We will ask you 10 questions. We expect that you will be in this research study for less than an hour.

Compensation
Your pay will not depend on your opinions: all good-faith responses will get fully compensated, so please just write what you think. You may not use ChatGPT or other AI tools to write or edit your responses. We will award a $1 bonus if your submission satisfies all minimum length requirements across all questions.

Who will see your responses?
The data you provide will be immediately anonymized. We may later on publish this anonymous data. By continuing this survey, you agree to this use of your responses.

Who can I talk to?
If you have questions, concerns, complaints, or think the research has hurt you, you can contact the research team at gilirusak@g.harvard.edu.

If the fertalized egg doesnt have limbs then it should be acceptable. Im not scientist or anything but all woman should have the right to their own bodies but not given too much time.

Thank you for completing the survey!

Click below to register your survey completion with Prolific and return to their website.

Informed Consent

We are a team of university researchers. We want to understand in detail what people like you think about social questions, in this case about abortion. We want to study the diversity of people’s beliefs, and whether algorithmic tools can help summarize and analyze these differing points of view.

We will ask you 10 questions. We expect that you will be in this research study for less than an hour.

Compensation
Your pay will not depend on your opinions: all good-faith responses will get fully compensated, so please just write what you think. You may not use ChatGPT or other AI tools to write or edit your responses. We will award a $1 bonus if your submission satisfies all minimum length requirements across all questions.

Who will see your responses?
The data you provide will be immediately anonymized. We may later on publish this anonymous data. By continuing this survey, you agree to this use of your responses.

Who can I talk to?
If you have questions, concerns, complaints, or think the research has hurt you, you can contact the research team at gilirusak@g.harvard.edu.

Part 1/3: Background Questions

We will begin by asking you 4 questions touching on specific parts of your opinion.

Background Questions

How often do think about abortion or discuss it with others? How does this topic make you feel?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: As someone assigned female at birth, I'd say I think about abortion a fairly average amount for those who have the potential to become pregnant. I am on birth control and tend to use condoms as well to hinder the chance of unwanted pregnancy, particularly due to the overturning of Roe. I live in New York City so I know my options regarding abortion are much more vast than those living in the South and middle-America. I am incredibly grateful for these options but also feel increasingly sad for those who cannot afford to move or have little access to women's healthcare. I discuss this topic with friends often as the growing limitations surrounding abortion and other healthcare like gender-affirming hormones make me angry. It feels very frustrating that the government has a say in how people live within their bodies. I am angry for all those who have been forced to carry to term against their will and I believe abortion, especially in the first trimester, should be a protected right for all those with the ability to get pregnant.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: As I stated in the first question, I absolutely believe abortion should be legal and a protected right. I believe all women and those with the potential to carry should have the ability to choose whether or not they are willing to provide their body, their time, and their lives to a baby. Pregnancy is a beautiful thing, but so is choice. I feel many pro-life advocates fail to recognize the impact of creating something entirely dependent on you. They also fail to see how much damage growing up in a home where a parent did not want them can do to a child. I think that abortions past 24 weeks should not necessarily be illegal - late-term abortion can become a necessity for women whose lives are endangered by their pregnancy. I am not a doctor, but I believe after 24 weeks, depending on medical research, abortion should become a case-by-case basis.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I grew up in a very liberal city in the Bay Area of California, which greatly influenced how I view social issues. My parents taught me to be accepting of those who are different than myself and to reach for empathy before judgment. Many of my friends have expressed fear of pregnancy and the overwhelming idea of having to raise a human being for a minimum of eighteen years. I know people who have sought abortion and the relief they feel being rid of a life-altering responsibility they are not prepared for is one of the reasons I believe having options is important. Reading news stories of teenagers and women with health issues being forced through dangerous, painful pregnancies has also had a massive impact on my opinion.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: After the 24-week mark, the possibility of abortion becomes dicey due to the procedure being more complex than early-stage abortions and the danger that they can pose to both the baby and mother. It is also when abortion becomes more of an ethical/moral dilemma for me as it is when the baby has a chance of survival outside of the womb. Though the chance for survival at 24 weeks is slim, passing that mark is when the fetus has developed enough to stand a chance on its own. I think late-term abortion really should be looked at case-by-case. Abortions before 24 weeks have no moral dilemma for me as there is only the mother whose life is on the line - I do not think late-term abortion should be illegal due to fetal anomalies/endangerment to the mother and child, but I think they should be infrequent and only performed on necessity.

question_text:
Part 2/3: Your Position

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: I believe abortion before the 24-week mark should be a protected right for women and those able to carry a child, and late-term abortion should be legal with the advisement of an OBGYN/natal specialist. The right to bodily autonomy and the freedom of choice are rights those of us in America are taught are intrinsic, and the policies currently being levied against said rights are despicable and a huge step back for women's rights and society as a whole. The lives of the mother and unborn child are seen as equal to pro-lifers, however, through anti-abortion policies paired with contradicting anti-birth control sentiments, they put both lives they claim to cherish in danger.

question_text:
Part 3/3: Candidate Summaries

To help researchers and policymakers understand public opinion on abortion, we will condense the survey responses into a short summary. We will now present 5 candidate summaries to you, and your task is to rate to what extent they would capture your point of view.

An ideal summary should

  1. perfectly capture all your thoughts and feelings on abortion,
  2. include the reasoning behind your opinion, and
  3. be concrete and actionable.

Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be legal and accessible because women have the right to make decisions about their own bodies. Access to safe abortions is crucial for protecting women's health and well-being. Society should support comprehensive sex education and contraception to reduce the need for abortions.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree with all three of the statements in this summary. The need for comprehensive sex education and accessibility to contraceptives is a necessity in America and would greatly decrease unwanted pregnancies. I think it is strange that pro-life advocates are so against this sentiment, as it could support their cause of decreasing abortion within the country.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be allowed in the first trimester but restricted afterward unless there are exceptional circumstances. This policy respects a woman's right to choose while recognizing the increasing moral considerations as the pregnancy progresses. Society should invest in education and healthcare to prevent unwanted pregnancies and support women through their reproductive choices.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I almost entirely agree with this summary, I simply would extend a bit further past the first trimester to the 24-week mark. I definitely agree that late-term abortion must be dealt with case-by-case, and should be more of a necessity for survival/hindering complications. Again, the notion of endorsing better education and healthcare is an important point that would further both pro-life and pro-choice standpoints.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be a personal decision between a woman and her doctor, without government interference. Each situation is unique, and women should have the autonomy to make the best choice for themselves and their families. Society should ensure that all women have access to affordable healthcare, including reproductive services.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree with this summary - the government should have no right to how we delegate what happens within our bodies. Policies that endanger and remove rights from women are dystopian and should be looked at as such.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be restricted to certain circumstances, such as cases of rape, incest, or when the mother's life is at risk. This approach balances the rights of the unborn with the needs of women facing difficult situations. Society should provide support for women who carry their pregnancies to term, including healthcare and financial assistance.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree that the circumstances mentioned above should warrant abortion 100% of the time. I also agree that society should provide for women via accessible healthcare and financial assistance, however, I do not think that natal care of this sort should be restricted to women who carry to term. All women and people who face the possibility of pregnancy should be able to access healthcare that is supportive of them. We should not punish those who do not have the financial, emotional, or physical needs to carry and raise a baby - allowing those who have become pregnant from awful circumstances like rape to abort is essential, but allowing those who simply cannot support or do not want a child should be seen as a valid reason to abort as well.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be illegal because it involves taking a human life, which I consider morally wrong. Society should focus on providing resources and support for pregnant women to encourage them to choose life. Adoption should be promoted as a viable alternative to abortion.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree that resources and support should be provided to women, not to encourage them to choose life in the sense this summary defines, but to encourage the ability to choose what will be best for the mother's life. Decisions about pregnancy, especially early-term, should be entirely selfish and dictated by the woman carrying. Emphasizing adoption as a choice is important - it is an equally viable option for women who are not ready to raise a child. However, the foster care system and politics surrounding adoption in the United States are greatly flawed and should not be taken lightly. Many see abortion as the rash choice, the violent choice, but allowing a child to grow up unwanted, in potentially abusive situations, or as a means to an end through stipends or privatization is equally violent and cruel. Children should never grow up feeling unwanted and the potential for them to be harmed when born from an unwanted pregnancy is much greater.
