text: I think about abortion semi-frequently. If there are news regarding abortion, it will be on my mind for some time and I may participate in online discussions. When the issue of abortion comes to mind, I become worried for others and myself for how certain laws would come into play. I can get emotional particularly over hypothetical and real cases of rape and child abuse that may not fare well under these laws. When it comes to discussion with others, I usually do not bring it up to family, but I do bring it up with people I feel express the same opinions as me.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: Abortion should be legal without any restrictions. I do not think there is a single circumstance, even if the pregnancy is late-term, where abortion should be dissuaded. My thinking is based on the idea that the person who's carrying the fetus comes first and has a life, personality, and well-being of their own that should be saved before a being that hasn't come into existence yet and is not legally recognized.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: My beliefs about abortion come from reading other people's arguments, which have successfully switched me from a pro-life stance to a pro-choice one. I used to be against abortion except in cases of rape or child abuse, but others have pointed out such a belief would be incongruent with feminism and the value of letting women dictate their own bodies, which I align myself with. Personally, I am capable of becoming pregnant and have a fear of pregnancy, which also affects my opinion. I have a history of childhood sexual abuse and I emphasize with the idea of not having control over one's body. I can  easily imagine what it would be like to feel like people dictate the use of your body.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: While I fully believe abortion should be accepted in all cases regardless, I do think there is a borderline situation. When a fetus is almost or fully developed and the person is about to give birth soon, I feel like abortion should not be recommended. This is not out of wanting to preserve the fetus' life, but concern for the parent because it would be harder to recover physically and mentally from late-term abortions. It is also not recommended by doctors.

question_text:
Part 2/3: Your Position

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: Abortion should be fully allowed without restrictions because a fetus in someone's body is already not legally recognized as a separate person, meaning it is the choice of someone first and foremost what to do with their body. Society should constitutionalize or otherwise make legal protections for abortions, normalizing the idea of individual autonomy. Such legal protections would not only make it difficult for the government to encroach individuals' boundaries and lives, but set a precedent that public access to ANY personal medical information is forbidden.

question_text:
Part 3/3: Candidate Summaries

To help researchers and policymakers understand public opinion on abortion, we will condense the survey responses into a short summary. We will now present 5 candidate summaries to you, and your task is to rate to what extent they would capture your point of view.

An ideal summary should

  1. perfectly capture all your thoughts and feelings on abortion,
  2. include the reasoning behind your opinion, and
  3. be concrete and actionable.

Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be legal and accessible because women have the right to make decisions about their own bodies. Access to safe abortions is crucial for protecting women's health and well-being. Society should support comprehensive sex education and contraception to reduce the need for abortions.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree with the emphasis on women's right to decision-making as well as the solutions. There is no part I disagree with, but there could be the addition that the only way safe abortions is guaranteed is if it were written into law.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be illegal because it involves taking a human life, which I consider morally wrong. Society should focus on providing resources and support for pregnant women to encourage them to choose life. Adoption should be promoted as a viable alternative to abortion.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree with the idea that society should do a better job on proving resources and support for pregnant women, but not in order to persuade them to not abort. I disagree with abortion being illegal because it involves taking a human life as fetuses do not count as persons (cannot get an ID card, etc.). In addition, I disagree with adoption being a viable alternative since there are already numerous children through the adoption system who struggle with mental health and finding a family who accepts them. What would fully represent my viewpoint would require changing all sentences to something along the lines of, "Abortion should be legal because fetuses are not legally recognized as people and cannot be killed. Society should focus on providing resources and support for pregnant women to make an informed decision. Contraception and sex education would help lower the need for abortion."

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be a personal decision between a woman and her doctor, without government interference. Each situation is unique, and women should have the autonomy to make the best choice for themselves and their families. Society should ensure that all women have access to affordable healthcare, including reproductive services.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree with all parts, liking the emphasis on abortion being a personal decision with no government interference. There is no part I disagree with. I would make it more clear that abortion should be legally protected, which would encourage reproductive services to flourish.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be allowed in the first trimester but restricted afterward unless there are exceptional circumstances. This policy respects a woman's right to choose while recognizing the increasing moral considerations as the pregnancy progresses. Society should invest in education and healthcare to prevent unwanted pregnancies and support women through their reproductive choices.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree with abortion being allowed as well as the idea that society should invest in education and healthcare to support women's reproductive choices. I think the societal policy would be a universal benefit because women would experience less distress over making reproductive decisions. However, I do not agree with restrictions. While I can see the line of thought with respecting the woman's right to choose, it is still restricting their choice nevertheless. It is still allowing the government and others to say what someone should do with their body. I would change the summary to say abortion should be allowed without restrictions and make the preceding reasons more concrete (policies without restrictions would protect a woman's right to choose inequitably). The last sentence can stay.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be restricted to certain circumstances, such as cases of rape, incest, or when the mother's life is at risk. This approach balances the rights of the unborn with the needs of women facing difficult situations. Society should provide support for women who carry their pregnancies to term, including healthcare and financial assistance.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree with the last sentence that society should provide support for women who carry pregnancies to term. However, I do not agree with everything else because it is criminalizing abortion by restricting it, even to support women in difficult situations. Someone can need an abortion because they were raised uneducated and poor and did not know sex would lead to pregnancy, for example, and they would be excluded from this policy even if their circumstances were unfortunate. I would change it to abortion should be unrestricted as it would not discriminate against which woman deserves sympathy and protection under law.

question_text:
Thank you for completing the survey!

Click below to register your survey completion with Prolific and return to their website.

Informed Consent

We are a team of university researchers. We want to understand in detail what people like you think about social questions, in this case about abortion. We want to study the diversity of people’s beliefs, and whether algorithmic tools can help summarize and analyze these differing points of view.

What will I need to do and how long will the study last?
We will ask you 10 questions. We expect that you will be in this research study for less than an hour.

Compensation
Your pay will not depend on your opinions: all good-faith responses will get fully compensated, so please just write what you think. You may not use ChatGPT or other AI tools to write or edit your responses. We will award a $1 bonus if your submission satisfies all minimum length requirements across all questions.

Who will see your responses?
The data you provide will be immediately anonymized. We may later on publish this anonymous data. By continuing this survey, you agree to this use of your responses.

Who can I talk to?
If you have questions, concerns, complaints, or think the research has hurt you, you can contact the research team at gilirusak@g.harvard.edu.

Part 1/3: Background Questions

We will begin by asking you 4 questions touching on specific parts of your opinion.

Background Questions

How often do think about abortion or discuss it with others? How does this topic make you feel?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I honestly do not think about abortion often at all. It maybe comes up in conversation once every few months when I am around family that have passionate opinions on it. The topic of abortion is a bit difficult for me. I am surrounded by people who have all kinds of different opinions on it, and mine do not exactly match any of them. It makes me feel like I want to stay away from it entirely. I also have a long history of fertility issues, so anything to do with fertility is a difficult topic for me.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I believe that it should be legal until the fetus is viable unless the mother and baby's life are in danger. If that baby has any chance of survival outside of the womb, even with major medical intervention, they should not be aborted unless the circumstances are extreme and life threatening. I believe that gives people enough time to find out they are pregnant and take the time to make the decision. I personally would not have one myself unless the child would not live or the pregnancy would kill me, but I believe other people should have the right to choose differently as long as the baby would not be viable.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I believe my personal feeling on abortion are a mixture of the religion I was raised in, the opinion of those around me of all backgrounds, and my personal life experiences. I will say my personal belief for what I would do with my own body differs from what I think others should have access to.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: The gray line for me is if it is on the edge if the baby would survive without the parent or not. It is a hard line to say when that should be. Technology is getting better every day, so the chances of younger fetuses surviving go up every day. It is a hard thing to regulate.

question_text:
Part 2/3: Your Position

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: I personally would not get an abortion for myself unless me or the baby were at risk of death, with that being said, I believe that other people should have the right to choose differently. I do believe that having a late term abortion where the baby could be viable outside or the parent with medical intervention or not should not be legal. To me, that is no different than killing a baby that was born at term. Someone would be arrested for that. I see no difference. I believe that a person has plenty of time to find out they are pregnant and make a thoughtful decision about how they want to go forward before the baby would be viable. I strongly do not believe that people should NOT be able to put of the decision until the baby could survive without the parent. I believe that a board of doctors certified to make the decision of when a fetus could survive, even with medical intervention, should get together a vote on the number of weeks that happens by, and we should go off of that. I would say we even subtract a small amount of time from that just to be safe.

text: While I do agree with "Society should ensure that all women have access to affordable healthcare, including reproductive services.”, I just cannot agree with the rest of it. Everything needs to have some regulation. Everyone needs to answer to someone. This is how we keep everything in check and the world from going into madness. So many parts of the medical field are regulated for everyone's safety. This should be no different.

Part 1/3: Background Questions

We will begin by asking you 4 questions touching on specific parts of your opinion.

Background Questions

How often do think about abortion or discuss it with others? How does this topic make you feel?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think about the topic of abortion quite a bit more than I used to. I would say that it would come up with others twice a week. It is an extremely delicate topic, and I notice that whenever it is brought up, I tend to shy away from it as much as the other individual. I feel perplexed, concerned with the moral aspect, and my religious views on it with regard to the importance of separation of church and state.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text:
I believe it should be legal. I have come to this conclusion as a result of many factors that I will soon explain but at the heart of it I see abortion as a moral grey zone. Abortion technically should not be legal in many cases such as when an individual knows and understands that they can become pregnant but do not have the decency to try to prevent it. They then use abortion as a get out of it quick situation. I believe this is wrong on the moral level and degrades society to some degree with the relaxed view regarding taking an unborn child's life. 

You may wonder why I say that it should be legal in this case. My answer is that there are far too many complicated situations that arise due to life in general that will unfortunately necessitate it. In cases of rape, the individual that was raped should not have to reward the rapist with a child as a result of a horrendous crime against humanity. I understand it is an unborn child, however it was not conceived in a mutual way. If the person raped chooses to have the child, I believe it is completely up to them but the opening to abort the fetus at that point is absolutely understandable. Then there is the situation of birth defects and severe genetic issues that may warrant an abortion to simply prevent suffering of the unborn child that would be cruel and tragic if the child were to be born. This is a horrible fact of life, but parents should be able to abort a pregnancy if they believe that a I child would suffer throughout their life and not be able to live one that is fulfilling. As technology gets better it will happen less often and that is really the best we can hope for in this situation.  Abortion due to economic inability is horrible but we have no better solution to that yet. 

It ultimately comes down to a grey zone of necessity and compassion in conflict with morality and obligation. I do not believe that a woman should simply be able to have a child aborted simply because she feels like it. Doing so to hurt a man that wanted to have a child with her out of spite would be completely wrong from a moral and ethical standpoint. My decision to seek for it to be legal is because I understand that there are many more situations that may be helped with its legality than situations where it would create harm.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I do not have any particular life experiences directly related to a situation regarding abortion. I was born in a very Christian family and went to a Christian school my entire life. I entered a public university and spent around three years in college. My beliefs come from an understanding of the sanctity of life but also with an understanding of the tragedy of life and the many horrible circumstances that people have to endure at times. As a Christian I believe life is sacred, but you do not have to be a born again Christian to believe that. I like to be a very thoughtful individual and look at as many angles as possible to come up with what I feel is the best possible belief regarding a topic. That is the best way I can explain my belief on this issue.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: The only situation where I feel it is questionable is in a situation where a mother is dying and has asked her partner to save the life of the child instead of her own. If she is already a mother of say two children, then this request would put a very undue burden on her partner as a result. Should the partner deny her request to save the child instead? I believe that the mother should probably be saved in this situation, but I can't truly be certain here. If she has no other children, then this would still put an unfair burden on her partner as well. Her believed selfless choice could have dire consequences for her partner and child for decades to come.

question_text:
Part 2/3: Your Position

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: Abortion should be legal and respected in situations that warrant it due to situations beyond our control. Rape, Incest, and genetic defects along with other issues place an unfair and cruel burden on the mother that should allow her the ability to make the best choice possible for herself. Abortion should be legal in other situations such as undue economic burdens and simple inability to care for the child but with an understanding that it should be a choice made quickly and not months into the pregnancy.

question_text:
Part 3/3: Candidate Summaries

To help researchers and policymakers understand public opinion on abortion, we will condense the survey responses into a short summary. We will now present 5 candidate summaries to you, and your task is to rate to what extent they would capture your point of view.

An ideal summary should

  1. perfectly capture all your thoughts and feelings on abortion,
  2. include the reasoning behind your opinion, and
  3. be concrete and actionable.

Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be allowed in the first trimester but restricted afterward unless there are exceptional circumstances. This policy respects a woman's right to choose while recognizing the increasing moral considerations as the pregnancy progresses. Society should invest in education and healthcare to prevent unwanted pregnancies and support women through their reproductive choices.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree that abortion should restricted to the first trimester as it creates major moral issues as time goes on. Preventative healthcare is a superb point and preventing a pregnancy from occurring to begin with is really the best option possible until an individual is prepared to become pregnant.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be illegal because it involves taking a human life, which I consider morally wrong. Society should focus on providing resources and support for pregnant women to encourage them to choose life. Adoption should be promoted as a viable alternative to abortion.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I understand the issue with human life. I also realize that the number of resources required to support a woman with a child can be very expensive and many taxpayers would rather not foot a bill for what they consider someone's poor choices in life. I think adoption is great but these homes for children are already crowded and the natural primal instinct of most people is to sire their own children and carry on their own genetic code. I think it is an unfortunate reality that may sound selfish, but it is ingrained in us.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be legal and accessible because women have the right to make decisions about their own bodies. Access to safe abortions is crucial for protecting women's health and well-being. Society should support comprehensive sex education and contraception to reduce the need for abortions.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I can't disagree with this statement overall because it does make a good point. Reducing the need to have abortions is in my opinion far more important than simply discussing abortion itself. I wish the statement would show more care for the unborn child instead of focusing solely on women's health and wellbeing. It comes across as biased.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be restricted to certain circumstances, such as cases of rape, incest, or when the mother's life is at risk. This approach balances the rights of the unborn with the needs of women facing difficult situations. Society should provide support for women who carry their pregnancies to term, including healthcare and financial assistance.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: This really hits the nail on the head as far as I am concerned. It understands the necessity of abortion in certain circumstances and acknowledges difficult situations that often cannot be helped. I also agree that society should provide more support for women who desired to have children and encourage motherhood.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be a personal decision between a woman and her doctor, without government interference. Each situation is unique, and women should have the autonomy to make the best choice for themselves and their families. Society should ensure that all women have access to affordable healthcare, including reproductive services.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think this focuses far too much on women's rights without really acknowledging the issues that abortion can bring up. I agree with affordable healthcare, but I feel trying to prevent pregnancies needs to be primary to other services in this part of healthcare.

Part 1/3: Background Questions

We will begin by asking you 4 questions touching on specific parts of your opinion.

Background Questions

How often do think about abortion or discuss it with others? How does this topic make you feel?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think about it occasionally, but not so frequently that it dominates my life. It has come up with some friends, and it has come up with my partner more than once, as we had to make the choice to end a pregnancy last year. It was a very hard choice, but, it was the choice that was best for us. It doesn't make me feel great to talk about. Abortion is a very personal choice and carries a lot of emotional weight for me.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think abortion needs to be legal, up until viability, in every case. Forcing someone to carry a pregnancy and bring a child into the world who will likely not receive the love or care that they deserve because of the circumstances is cruel.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: My beliefs come from quite a few factors. I have had an abortion, and while it was not an enjoyable experience, it was one that I needed to have to maintain a stable environment for my already living son. My beliefs are also formed by my religious beliefs, which hinge upon each person maintaining their own bodily autonomy. Besides those, there are political beliefs that I ascribe to that also include women having the right to control their own bodies.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: The only situation where I think abortion would be immoral and inappropriate would be past the point of viability. To clarify, I do not mean simply "life" in the sense that the child will exist but immediately die after birth or other horrible circumstances. I mean specifically a healthy child with no life hindering birth defects that is past the point of viability.

question_text:
Part 2/3: Your Position

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: Abortion is an entirely personal and private medical choice that no one else needs to be privy to, and essential healthcare for every woman. There are many circumstances where having a child could be detrimental medically, physically, emotionally, financially, or socially to a mother. Society should, as a whole, refer to women to make the best choice for their body and their own lives, without judgement or criminality being involved, as women who are in the best position to choose when they have a family will raise the most well adjusted, loved, and happy children if they choose to do so -- without regret or resentment of the mother poisoning the entire life of an innocent child.

question_text:
Part 3/3: Candidate Summaries

To help researchers and policymakers understand public opinion on abortion, we will condense the survey responses into a short summary. We will now present 5 candidate summaries to you, and your task is to rate to what extent they would capture your point of view.

An ideal summary should

  1. perfectly capture all your thoughts and feelings on abortion,
  2. include the reasoning behind your opinion, and
  3. be concrete and actionable.

Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be illegal because it involves taking a human life, which I consider morally wrong. Society should focus on providing resources and support for pregnant women to encourage them to choose life. Adoption should be promoted as a viable alternative to abortion.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think for many reasons, that the view of the author in this summary are incredibly flawed. Adoption being an option would need for there to be enough prospective adoptive parents out there to actually care for all of the children born into the world forcibly. Adoption is incredibly expensive, and something that is only afforded to very few as a real, honest choice. Adopted children, such as my mother, are often also left with lifelong mental issues that stem from the inherent abandonment of being adopted out, and in turn can make incredibly terrible parents and people in general. Adoption does not remove the physical and emotional damage to a mother caused by giving birth. Women, especially women of color, are at risk of DEATH when giving birth, as well as life long complications. It is entirely possible that being forced to carry an unwanted pregnancy could damage a woman internally to the point that she is not able to have another child when she is ready. A woman who is forced to carry a pregnancy that stems from sexual assault may be damaged for life emotionally and never get past the trauma. A woman who is ready for a child, who has a fetus inside of her that is born without a brain and only a brainstem that will die shortly after birth, who is forced to carry this child to term, would be scarred for life by the emotional toll of feeling their very loved and very wanted baby in their arms slowly wither and die. There are so many other equally horrific birth defects that leave a child to live minutes, hours, days, weeks, or months at most, that will forever scar a parent and potentially keep them from ever having another child or having a happy life. It is a cruel, thoughtless position to force women to carry a child to term that they are not ready for, because it involves divorcing yourself from the reality that a woman is not a broodmare, and instead a human being who is ALSO a life worth cherishing and protecting.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be restricted to certain circumstances, such as cases of rape, incest, or when the mother's life is at risk. This approach balances the rights of the unborn with the needs of women facing difficult situations. Society should provide support for women who carry their pregnancies to term, including healthcare and financial assistance.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: This is also a horrible summary and completely ignores fatal birth defects of a child as a reason to abort. Mental health of the mother is also nowhere in this, which, is necessary -- while it isn't a direct risk to a mother's health, the mental toll of pregnancy can ruin someone's life. It also makes zero mention of a plan for all of these forced births. None. Who exactly is going to care for all of these new children, including children with birth defects and disabilities, who are often ignored and overlooked for adoption? This is a very shallow and immature way of looking at the problem which completely ignores a woman's bodily autonomy.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be legal and accessible because women have the right to make decisions about their own bodies. Access to safe abortions is crucial for protecting women's health and well-being. Society should support comprehensive sex education and contraception to reduce the need for abortions.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think that the message is somewhat well written, but still fails to support itself with more detailed points. Using specific examples would make me grade this better.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be allowed in the first trimester but restricted afterward unless there are exceptional circumstances. This policy respects a woman's right to choose while recognizing the increasing moral considerations as the pregnancy progresses. Society should invest in education and healthcare to prevent unwanted pregnancies and support women through their reproductive choices.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: A substantial amount of women, myself included, may not realize they are pregnant at all in the first trimester, so an arbitrary date like this leaves many people suddenly without any choice in their own body. Hormonal issues, birth control failure, and other reasons can cause someone to not realize they are pregnant past the first trimester. I was 4.5 months pregnant before I realized, because my birth control - which keeps me from having a period - had failed and I wasn't aware. If I was a drinker, this scenario would have forced me to give birth to a child that likely had fetal alcohol syndrome or another birth defect, and would force that fate upon other innocent women, and leave thousands of disabled children with parents who resent them or no family at all. Disabled children are not adopted readily. It also does not state in this what "exceptional circumstances" is. There are many flaws that need to be critically evaluated outside of "morals" -- especially since morals are subjective. Your morals cannot dictate the actions of others and others may not share your morals.

Each situation is unique, and women should have the autonomy to make the best choice for themselves and their families. How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think this is well written and concise. I do however think that there are not enough details which support the conclusion.

This is also how most women I talk to about the issue also feel and I would generally refer to them on this issue. I also am not a huge fan of pulling out either.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: It should be legal in almost all circumstances. I don't really think there is a situation where an abortion shouldn't be legal. I know some late term pregnancy's can get questionable if the baby is alive at that point or not. I would refer to medical health experts, but again I feel like abortions that are medically necessary for the person giving birth are always fine.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

text: I don't think there is any particular life event that shaped my belief. I think for the most part it comes from the fact that no child should be forced into a situation where their own parent didn't want them. Some people get pregnant in situations where it isn't sustainable to raise a child and that child deserves all the conditions necessary for their success.

question_text:
Background Questions

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I mean I said earlier that some late term pregnancies' are questionable about whether the child is alive or not. But again I would refer to medical health experts and would prioritize the well-being of the mother and not the child.

question_text:

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: Abortions should be completely legal in all circumstances and the well-being of the mother should be prioritized. Abortions are a necessary tool for woman to enact agency over their wombs. They should be in control of whether or not they are bringing a child into this world, given all the conditions and things necessary for a child to thrive in this world. Abortions not only benefit woman, but also the potential child from living in potentially desolate conditions that they were never meant to.

Part 1/3: Background Questions

We will begin by asking you 4 questions touching on specific parts of your opinion.

Background Questions

How often do think about abortion or discuss it with others? How does this topic make you feel?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I don't think about abortion every single day, but I do think about it often. It affects me quite closely, seeing as I am a woman, who is very scared of pregnancy. I do not want to be pregnant or give birth. But thankfully I live in a state where abortion rights are protected (for now). But the possibility of that changing, is something I talk about with my family. I would say I discuss it with others maybe once or twice a month. More, when elections are mentioned, as we go over which candidates support abortion rights.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think abortion should be legal in all cases. It is fundamentally wrong to force a woman to carry a baby within her body. That's her body and her right to not produce a baby, doesn't matter how the pregnancy happened. There are no circumstances my answer depends on. It should be legal in every single case.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: My beliefs on abortion come from stories of women dying or almost dying giving birth, millions upon millions of women's bodies irreversibly damaged from giving birth (incontinence issues, 3rd degree tearing, pelvic floor issues, gestational diabetes that doesn't go away after birth, etc), not to mention the mental health issues that can arise, such as post- and pre-partum depression, post- and pre-partum anxiety and psychosis, due to the high amount of hormones and mental changes that go into creating a child within one's body. In addition, I couldn't image the mental anguish and physical pain a woman would have to go through being pregnant and giving birth when she didn't want to. Regular, wanted births can cause PTSD. Birth is a traumatic medical event. To force that on someone unwilling is akin to cruel and unusual punishment that is outlawed for use on prisoners. So why should we force that on our own citizens?

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: The only situation I can think of would be live birth "abortion" but that's not even an abortion, at that point, due to the fact that the baby was already being born at the time of the "abortion". I do believe that is completely illegal and should be, because the baby being born no longer makes abortion possible. Abortion needs to be done before the baby is born.

question_text:
Part 2/3: Your Position

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: Society should make all abortions legal, in every state, for any reason. This is because forcing a woman to carry a pregnancy and give birth is fundamentally wrong, and infringes on her right to her own body, as well as her right to not undergo cruel and unusual punishment. Pregnancy and giving birth is medically risky, and causes many irreversible medical and mental issues, and to impose that on citizens should be illegal.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I disagree with every single thing this candidate said. Adoption is not a viable alternative to abortion, because making a woman go through pregnancy and giving birth causes irreparable damage to her physically and mentally, akin to cruel and unusual punishment. So forcing a woman to go through that so they can adopt out the baby would not be the same as abortion, therefore adoption is fundamentally and unequivocally not a viable alternative. In addition, abortion does not take a human life, because when a fetus is in the womb, it is not viable. It cannot survive outside of the body, therefore it is not a human life.

Thank you for completing the survey!

Click below to register your survey completion with Prolific and return to their website.

Informed Consent

We are a team of university researchers. We want to understand in detail what people like you think about social questions, in this case about abortion. We want to study the diversity of people’s beliefs, and whether algorithmic tools can help summarize and analyze these differing points of view.

What will I need to do and how long will the study last?
We will ask you 10 questions. We expect that you will be in this research study for less than an hour.

Compensation
Your pay will not depend on your opinions: all good-faith responses will get fully compensated, so please just write what you think. You may not use ChatGPT or other AI tools to write or edit your responses. We will award a $1 bonus if your submission satisfies all minimum length requirements across all questions.

Who will see your responses?
The data you provide will be immediately anonymized. We may later on publish this anonymous data. By continuing this survey, you agree to this use of your responses.

Who can I talk to?
If you have questions, concerns, complaints, or think the research has hurt you, you can contact the research team at gilirusak@g.harvard.edu.

Part 1/3: Background Questions

We will begin by asking you 4 questions touching on specific parts of your opinion.

Background Questions

How often do think about abortion or discuss it with others? How does this topic make you feel?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: The topic of abortion is not a common topic that comes up as being discussed between myself or others. However, the few moments the topic has come up it is usually between myself and my wife and/or also my little sister. We all three have kind of concluded that we feel along the same lines as each other: though it is not something we personally feel we would need or want to get, women who do should have the option to do so for whatever reason it may be. It personally is not my cup of tea, however there is always a possibility it would be needed and not wanted and the option should be there regardless of the reasoning.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I believe abortion should be legal, a part of me feels sad saying so but it is not my right for someone else's body and/or choices. There is not a one size fits all on this topic and women should rightfully be able to choose how and why and what they need to do something for, it is not my choice what they need to do for their own lives.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I do not feel as if I have a specific reasoning for believing what I believe when it comes to abortion. Honestly, my mother had a hell of a time becoming pregnant and had lost three boys, one still birth, before ever having me and they would have given anything to have not gone through that. I wanted nothing more than to have my little girl I finally had, so my beliefs i try to keep solely based on playing devil's advocate and seeing things from both sides and someone's body just isn't where my focus and attention need to lie.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I cannot describe a situation where I am not sure if abortion is appropriate or not for two reasons: it is not my decision to decide whether abortion is appropriate or not case by case or at all. If a woman wants an abortion, she has her own reasoning and for me that is between her and herself, not I. I am not to judge someone and to me there is no right or wrong or anybody who can decide what is right or wrong or appropriate or not for someone else, if a woman wants an abortion a woman should be able to and does not need to explain herself.

question_text:
Part 2/3: Your Position

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: It is not society's jobs to deal with what a specific person wants for their body, it is not any of our business. I do not tell you what to do and why, and I highly doubt anybody else makes those choices for you and tells you why. It is not our jobs to judge, it is not our jobs to tell people how and why they need to do something because it is what we think; we are programmed differently, hell not even two of our OWN fingerprints are exactly the same nor the same as anybody's else's therefore we are each our own and need to worry about our own.

text: I generally don't think about it or discuss about abortion because its a very sensitive topic. I only talk about it when asked. However, I am pro-life. The topic makes me sad in general because most modern women believe abortion is a good choice and glorified, its as if its another choice of birth control. This is saddening. text: I believe abortion should be illegal. Although an abortion should only be carried out in certain/severe circumstances if there was rape, incest, severely abnormal fetuses, or the life of the mother is in danger. I stand on my view. Any other circumstance is wrong and treated as a form of birth control.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

text: My beliefs about abortion come from my conservative Christian values. I also have a friend who had an abortion and regret it so much that she even has dreams of her dead baby many times. She cried and told me she made the worst mistake of her life when she was young. My friend had an abortion because she and her boyfriend where not ready for kids. That is still not an excuse to abort. My friend now has a daughter, but my friend never told her daughter that she has a dead sibling.

text: The only situation I am unsure if abortion is appropriate or not is whether a mother is expecting a child and the fetus has serious genetic anomaly that could lead to severe physical and mental disabilities. Yes prenatal testing can be involved but there have been several stories where doctors see the fetus with abnormalities but are then born normal. In my humble opinion the severity of the fetus determines whether to abort the baby.

question_text:

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: Abortion should be illegal, and society should acknowledge that abortion is only legal under extreme circumstances including: rape, incest, health of the mother, and the fetus having a genetic anomaly that could lead to severe physical and mental disabilities. Granting an abortion should be a last resort and not be practiced on anyone outside these circumstances. Abortion is not to be used as a form of birth control.

Part 1/3: Background Questions

We will begin by asking you 4 questions touching on specific parts of your opinion.

Background Questions

How often do think about abortion or discuss it with others? How does this topic make you feel?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I try not to think about it very often because it upsets me, but I do occasionally talk about it with others or think about introspectively. The topic disgusts me because I view abortion as murder.  In some circumstances abortion is necessary to save a mother's life or in cases of extreme trauma (an underage girl being raped, etc.) But if it isn't life or death, I think abortion should never be an option. Some of my inner circle agree with me, others in my circle do not.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think it should be a 'case by case' basis.  I think mostly it should be illegal, because it's murder of a baby. But I also concede the fact that sometimes a fetus can be cancerous or a danger to the mother (if she is too young or there are other health complications.)  In cases where it's detrimental to the mother's health I think abortion should be available. I don't think it should be allowed for women willy-nilly though.  They're playing with the life of an unborn baby.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I would say my beliefs on abortion come partially from my religion and partially from my own point of view.  Women who have abortions are literally killing their unborn children- it doesn't matter how far along they might be. Those babies didn't ask to be conceived, and yet they receive the punishment. It isn't right. It's murder to an innocent and helpless being.  Morality gives me my views- though children and babies are also cherished in my religious teachings as well. So it's a combination of the two.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: Honestly, I can't really think of a middle ground where it would be a question.  If it's for selfish reasons like the 'mother doesn't want to have a kid, or be pregnant, or have her body change, etc' then it isn't acceptable.  But if it's for medical reasons like the baby isn't a baby and is in fact cancer cells, or menstrual blood glomped together.  Or if the mother is a young girl who was raped and can't carry the pregnancy to term safely- those would be acceptable because it isn't for vanity or selfish reasons- it's literally life or death.

question_text:
Part 2/3: Your Position

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: I believe abortion should mostly be illegal accept in the most dire of circumstances, because it is murder and morally wrong.  If the mother's health is in jeopardy, if the mother is too young to carry the baby to term, or if it isn't a baby but cancerous cells, then I think it should be accept and legal for the mother to get an abortion.  In short, it should only be illegal when it's a life or death situation- and for no other reason.

Part 1/3: Background Questions

We will begin by asking you 4 questions touching on specific parts of your opinion.

Background Questions

How often do think about abortion or discuss it with others? How does this topic make you feel?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I do not think about abortion, nor do I discuss it often with others. In the past 2 months, I did have a conversation about pro-choice or pro-life with a friend. This topic does not make me uncomfortable, but it does allow me to think about the general direction our country is taking in this political climate. I think it is a valid topic to discuss.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: In my honest opinion, I am pro-choice and I believe that abortion should be legal. I think the biggest circumstance that my answer depends on is the fact in which, whether or not the pregnant individual had become so as a result of consent, or if there was foulplay/sexual assault involved. In the case of the latter, I do believe that the individual should have the choice to abort the child.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: My beliefs come from a position of wanting justice for the individual involved. In the case that the pregnancy was a result of sexual assault, I do believe that the child may illicit a PTSD-like response from the mother. Although I am not sure if this is typically the case, I do believe that it is within the right of the mother to decide for herself. My beliefs are not coming from a particular life experience.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: A situation where I am not sure if abortion is the appropriate measure is if the child is in the last trimester prior to birth, and the mother makes a late decision to abort the child. I do believe that if an individual wants to abort a child, it should be done as soon as possible. By the time the abortion is done close to the birthdate of the child, it does make the validity of the decision a bit more unclear and calls for ethical insight.

question_text:
Part 2/3: Your Position

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: I believe that society should give an individual the choice to abort a child. Although the choice to abort a child may be the result of several different reasons including sexual assault, I believe it is a human right to make this decision. In the case that abortions are banned in the US, I believe that individuals will still take measures to abort the child.

question_text:
Part 3/3: Candidate Summaries

To help researchers and policymakers understand public opinion on abortion, we will condense the survey responses into a short summary. We will now present 5 candidate summaries to you, and your task is to rate to what extent they would capture your point of view.

An ideal summary should

  1. perfectly capture all your thoughts and feelings on abortion,
  2. include the reasoning behind your opinion, and
  3. be concrete and actionable.

Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be legal and accessible because women have the right to make decisions about their own bodies. Access to safe abortions is crucial for protecting women's health and well-being. Society should support comprehensive sex education and contraception to reduce the need for abortions.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree with all of the statements listed above. I think the statements do a very good job summarizing the candidate's viewpoint on the matter and make a concrete case for his/her opinion. I agree with the points made on supporting sex education and taking measures to ensure that women's health and well-being are protected.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be a personal decision between a woman and her doctor, without government interference. Each situation is unique, and women should have the autonomy to make the best choice for themselves and their families. Society should ensure that all women have access to affordable healthcare, including reproductive services.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I agree with all of the statements provided by the candidate. I do agree that autonomy is very important from an ethical standpoint and that society should support the overall wellbeing of female individuals. The candidate provides solid statements that summarize their viewpoints.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be allowed in the first trimester but restricted afterward unless there are exceptional circumstances. This policy respects a woman's right to choose while recognizing the increasing moral considerations as the pregnancy progresses. Society should invest in education and healthcare to prevent unwanted pregnancies and support women through their reproductive choices.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

text: I do agree that abortion should be done as soon as possible, preferably within the first trimester. However, depending on the individual circumstance, I do believe that there are some instances where an abortion should be considered post first trimester. However, I agree with all of the other statements made by the candidate, and I do believe that society should wholly support women's health and provide education on this matter.

question_text:

I do agree that society should provide support for women, and should emphasize the overall health and well-being of the individual. Although I do agree that abortion should be allowed in the case of certain circumstances, I think overall there should be no restrictions.

We will begin by asking you 4 questions touching on specific parts of your opinion.

Background Questions

How often do think about abortion or discuss it with others? How does this topic make you feel?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I don't discuss it often because I'm a widower and don't have children.  However, discussing the topic is somewhat uncomfortable to me because it is very controversial.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think it should be legal. Women who want to do it will do it regardless of legality, but if they need to resort to questionable abortion practices because they don't have a choice it is more likely that it will cause serious health issues.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: My beliefs come from my own background and observations throughout my life.  I was not influenced by any particular life experiences as I was not close enough to any woman who practiced abortion.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: One borderline situation is when tests reveal that the baby will have some defects. I don't think it should be necessarily illegal to carry out an abortion in this case, but is does raise some moral issues.

question_text:
Part 2/3: Your Position

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: I personally think that abortion may or may not be morally acceptable. From a moral point of view, it depends on the specific situation, such as how the woman became pregnant, her health conditions and the health of the baby. That said, I don't think that the government should make abortion illegal. It should always be a question of personal choice for the woman, and safe abortion practices should be available to women who decide to do it.

question_text:
Part 3/3: Candidate Summaries

To help researchers and policymakers understand public opinion on abortion, we will condense the survey responses into a short summary. We will now present 5 candidate summaries to you, and your task is to rate to what extent they would capture your point of view.

An ideal summary should

  1. perfectly capture all your thoughts and feelings on abortion,
  2. include the reasoning behind your opinion, and
  3. be concrete and actionable.

Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be legal and accessible because women have the right to make decisions about their own bodies. Access to safe abortions is crucial for protecting women's health and well-being. Society should support comprehensive sex education and contraception to reduce the need for abortions.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I fully agree with the statement. One point in the summary that I agree with and did not include in my own summary is the need to support sex education and contraception to reduce the need for abortions.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be a personal decision between a woman and her doctor, without government interference. Each situation is unique, and women should have the autonomy to make the best choice for themselves and their families. Society should ensure that all women have access to affordable healthcare, including reproductive services.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: Agree with everything, including the role of the government in providing affordable healthcare (which I do not include in my summary). I think the point about educational programs to reduce unnecessary cases of abortion (as cited by the previous summary) should also be included.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be allowed in the first trimester but restricted afterward unless there are exceptional circumstances. This policy respects a woman's right to choose while recognizing the increasing moral considerations as the pregnancy progresses. Society should invest in education and healthcare to prevent unwanted pregnancies and support women through their reproductive choices.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I don't think the government should restrict a woman's ability to make her own choices, as long as the possible risks of an abortion procedure are clearly explained to her.  I agree with the point about education and healthcare support.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I believe that abortion should be illegal because it involves taking a human life, which I consider morally wrong. Society should focus on providing resources and support for pregnant women to encourage them to choose life. Adoption should be promoted as a viable alternative to abortion.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I disagree with the main point that it should be illegal because it's morally wrong.  Morality really depends on the situation, I don't think the government should dictate what a woman should do with her body, as long as she is aware of possible alternatives, risks, etc. I agree that adoption can be a viable alternative to abortion, and I think it should be part of an educational program, but not an imposed solution.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries

Here is a possible summary:

“I think abortion should be restricted to certain circumstances, such as cases of rape, incest, or when the mother's life is at risk. This approach balances the rights of the unborn with the needs of women facing difficult situations. Society should provide support for women who carry their pregnancies to term, including healthcare and financial assistance.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I don't think society should restrict the option for a woman to have an abortion. It should be her own personal choice, whether society views it as immoral or not.  There may be many personal reasons why a woman wants to opt for abortion, and it should not be the role of the government to make that decision based on religion or other non-scientific values. As I mentioned before, providing enough education and information for the woman to make that choice is a crucial role of society.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: The conversation has come up, but it does not frequent my conversations. I am pro choice so I don't judge people who want to or don't want to get an abortion. I feel that pregnancy is an extremely person to the woman that is pregnant, it's her body, no one else has to go through the ups and downs of pregnancy. Women literally almost die giving birth, so I don't think the right to abort or not abort should be left up to anyone other than the mother that is pregnant.

question_text:
Background Questions

Do you think abortion should be legal or illegal? Which circumstances does your answer depend on?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I think abortion should be legal. I think people overestimate how often people are getting abortions or the reason people get them. Yes, some people should learn to use protection or abstain, however, every situation is different. We never know the reason someone may want or need an abortion. I said before I think this is a decision personal to the woman that is pregnant. No one else can make a decision for al life they don't have to live.

question_text:
Background Questions

Where do your beliefs about abortion come from? For example, did particular life experiences influence your beliefs?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: My beliefs about abortion come from my own mind and my personal life experiences. I am an open minded and very empathetic person. I am a woman, I have not gotten pregnant yet or had kids yet, but as a woman that deals with other women related health issues, I don't like the idea of someone that doesn't live in my body trying to tell me what's best for me. I don't see how people want to control and dictate what happens in a life they will not and do not live. No other person should have autonomy over my body but me.

question_text:
Background Questions

Can you describe a situation where you are not sure if abortion is appropriate or not? If so, what makes this situation borderline or unclear?

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I don't like the idea of an abortion if the mother is very clearly past the normal range of getting one. While I understand it is a hard decision, there is a timeframe for a reason. I think to be ethical and do what's best for you and the unborn baby, you should abort way before you get too far along. Other than that, I think the decision still remains in the hands of the woman.

question_text:
Part 2/3: Your Position

This part only has one question. We will ask you to summarize, in three sentences, your overall position on abortion.

Your Position

Summarize your position on abortion in your own words. Please write how you think society should deal with abortions, and give reasons that support this policy.

Please write exactly 3 sentences: Be as precise as possible and prioritize the points that are most important to you. Your answer should be self-contained, which means that you can repeat things you already wrote as well as make new points.
text: My position on abortion is I am neither for nor against it. I am pro choice of the woman. I think society should take their personal beliefs out when making decisions that don't affect them personally. I think society acts like women are objects to be governed, and we are not. A man would never want a woman or anyone else telling them what they can and cannot do with their body, so I don't see why that's acceptable to do to women. I think society is more concerned about the life of an unborn child rather than focusing on the life the child will have if they are born. They also don't consider the toll pregnancy takes on women's bodies, and they don't consider that some women almost die or do die during pregnancy. I don't think we should focus on banning abortions, I think we need to worry about pushing safe sex and protection so that women don't end up in the situation to have to make a decision to abort or not.

“I believe that abortion should be illegal because it involves taking a human life, which I consider morally wrong. Society should focus on providing resources and support for pregnant women to encourage them to choose life. Adoption should be promoted as a viable alternative to abortion.”

How well does this summary capture your viewpoint on abortion? Explain which parts you agree with, which parts you disagree with, and what would need to be added or made more concrete to fully represent your viewpoint.

(Please write two or more sentences.)
text: I disagree with his summary, we have opposite viewpoints. I don't believe in the "involves taking human life" because pregnancy can and has taken human life too. How will the child have a happy life if their mother dies giving birth. The life of the unborn child also matters, so just bringing all children into the world isn't always what's best. I agree that resources should be provided for women, but I don't think that they should be encouraged to choose life. I think resources should be provided to women so they can have safe protected sex, and I believe resources and education should be provided to men considering there are many men that don't feel responsible for getting women pregnant. There are men that feel they shouldn't have to use protection. Education an resources need to be provided to men and women to prevent this from happening. I completely disagree with the adoption argument as well. The system is so flawed and over crowded. So many people are abused and not properly cared for in the system. Adoption is an option, but it is not the answer. You never know what conditions that child will grow up in so assuming adoption guarantees a better life for the child is false and delusional.

question_text:
Candidate Summaries
